name: Președintele. –
text: The first item is the debate on the Commission Declaration on the situation of migrants at the EU border with Bosnia and Herzegovina (2018/2971(RSP)).

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, as the Commissioners and Members of this House have been doing in the last two days, please allow me to express my solidarity with the families of the victims of the terrible attacks here in Strasbourg and solidarity with France and the French people. Thank you for the opportunity to discuss the situation of migrants at the border between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. First, let me give you the general picture. Bosnia and Herzegovina was not affected by the 2015 migratory crisis. However, between 1 January and 30 November 2018, around 23 000 migrants entered the country, a substantial increase compared to 2017, but still manageable. Ninety—two percent expressed their intention to ask for asylum, but only five did so. Most of them seek to go to EU countries. Migrants primarily consider Bosnia and Herzegovina, as other Western Balkan countries, a transit country. As of 4 December, there are currently 4 139 migrants and asylum seekers receiving assistance in Bosnia and Herzegovina, 3 126 of them in the Una-Sana Canton in the north—west corner of the country and close to the border with Croatia. One thousand additional migrants who have not yet requested assistance are estimated to be present in the area. The Commission responded immediately to the needs of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Since June 2018 the Commission has made available a substantial amount of funds to, first, address the immediate needs of refugees, asylum seekers and migrants; second, to provide adequate accommodation and basic services; third, to increase the capacity of identification; and, fourth, to support the Bosnia and Herzegovina border police. This includes EUR 2 million in humanitarian aid and EUR 7.2 million via a special measure of the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA). These are implemented by the International Organisation for Migration (IOM), in cooperation with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) and the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF). These funds are in addition to those already allocated for Bosnia and Herzegovina via the main IPA, notably on border management, migration and asylum. Thanks to European Union assistance, migrants in the Una—Sana Canton are reallocated from informal sites to organised reception centres. The objective is to ensure appropriate accommodation conditions. Four thousand persons now have a roof for the winter and nobody is left out in the cold. Sixty—one children will soon start their school year in the primary schools of Una—Sana Canton. Further assistance to Bosnia and Herzegovina will be available to cover the needs from April 2019 onwards. This will be based on the assessment by authorities. As you know, negotiations with Bosnia and Herzegovina for a status agreement for the deployment of European border and coastguard teams have been concluded. We look forward to signing the agreement as soon as possible. The status agreement will allow for assistance to the border police in managing the border between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, but the primary responsibility remains of course with the two countries. In recent weeks, Bosnia and Herzegovina has deployed 180 additional police officers to improve border security. Relations between the Bosnia and Herzegovina border police and the migrants seems to be positive overall, as reported to European Union officials. But, as I said, Bosnia and Herzegovina is a transit country and many migrants try to cross the border every day. The situation is also not easy for the local population, which reports tensions and fear of security incidents. Over recent months there have been reports of serious allegations of mistreatment of migrants by the Croatian police at the border with Bosnia and Herzegovina. The Commission has been actively and closely monitoring these developments and raised these allegations with the Croatian authorities. Let me stress that the EU Readmission Agreement should be applied to migrants illegally crossing the EU borders. It should be applied without prejudice to the right to apply for asylum and, more generally, of the rights, obligations and responsibilities of the Member States arising from international law, notably of course the principle of non—refoulement. The Croatian Ombudsman, Lora Vidovic, presented a report in October to the Croatian Parliament in which she voiced her concerns that the police were violating migrants’ right to international protection and obstructing the authority to obtain information. We are closely monitoring the situation. We all agree that the border between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina is an external European Union border and Croatia is responsible for its management. The measures at the EU’s external borders must be proportionate and comply with respect for fundamental rights. Let me conclude by underlining that we are confident that the Croatian authorities will take the allegations seriously and conduct swift and thorough investigations. Second, border guards and police authorities in all Member States are expected to carry out their duties in full respect of fundamental rights.

name: Dubravka Šuica
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Mr. Chairman, I hope mr. Commissioner that you are aware that Croatia's border is the longest border of the European Union, with Bosnia and Herzegovina almost 1000 kilometers, a total of 1300 kilometers, and that we are preparing to enter the Schengen system. Therefore, the Croatian police do everything in accordance with the regulations to ensure croatia's possibility of entering the Schengen zone, while at the same time trying to respect all international regulations and all the rules.  You yourself said that the number of migrants increased and that Bosnia and Herzegovina was not on the route in 2015, which is not the case now. The data, very fresh, from the Ministry of Interior of the Republic of Croatia say that this is a concrete increase of 57%, which means a total of 6415 persons compared to 2017. Likewise, 6,500 migrants are in makeshift accommodation near the border with Croatia. Basically, due to the facilitated visa regime of Bosnia and Herzegovina with certain third countries, in the first place with Turkey, the number of irregular crossings from Bosnia and Herzegovina has increased. Unfortunately, due to the visa mismatch of some other countries in the Western Balkans with the European Union visa regime, there is a greater migratory risk.  In any case, the fact is that the border of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as Albania and Montenegro, is being worked on. Croatia has more border police officers than all these three countries combined. Of course the asylum system in Bosnia and Herzegovina, but also in other countries in the Western Balkans, needs to be strengthened. Also, the conditions of the voluntary return scheme should be ensured. As you know, Croatia provides bilateral assistance to other countries on the Western Balkans migration route, and you also mentioned the assistance provided by the European Commission, after the European Council. Thus, it is almost 2 million euros in humanitarian aid and 6 million euros in aid to strengthen reception centres.  In any case, the Croatian authorities are working on this problem to the maximum, but at the same time taking into account that Croatia is the external border and that we want to become part of the Schengen area.

name: Tanja Fajon
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. The story of defectors who found themselves on the border between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Croatia is strongly reminiscent of other migrant stories that we have already seen, and there is no warm welcome from the local population, some political options abuse the unfortunate fates of migrants to incite hatred, and there is also fake news circulating around the country about refugees abducting girls and raping minors. I join some international organisations, even though the situation has improved, to provide emergency financial assistance to the country.  You mentioned, Commissioner, the obligations of the border authorities at the border with Croatia, and I particularly join croatia to help, and especially bosnia and Herzegovina, in a humanitarian way, to try to regulate the situation with migrants and to ensure that there is no trafficking in human beings and safe border crossings.

name: Ruža Tomašić
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. – Mr. Chairman, the accumulation of migrants in Bosnia and Herzegovina is very worrying and the country does not have the capacity to deal with this challenge, which in addition to political, humanitarian and security gains a public health dimension. Migrants are staying in inhumane conditions, with basic supplies and medical assistance lacking. The difficult position forces them to penetrate Croatia, which shares a long and very porous border with Bosnia and Herzegovina. Despite strong efforts by Croatian police, migrant groups are increasingly penetrating Croatia, with locals the victim of thefts and break-ins.  Croatia will not become a so-called hot spot and will continue to guard its european border. Logistical and financial assistance is needed to do so as successfully as possible. It is also important that in these circumstances Croatia is admitted to Schengen as soon as it meets all the requirements. This would send a strong message that the Union stands behind all its members, especially those under direct pressure from migrant waves.

name: Ivan Jakovčić
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Dear Chairman, there are two reasons why I have proposed that we discuss this situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina, on the border with Croatia, on the border with the European Union.  The first reason is certainly the humanistic reason, the human reason. The situation of migrants, the situation in which children freeze, the problem of education and children and everything that happens to them in a difficult way, but also problems in relations with the local population and the violence that exists among the migrants themselves, the fear of the local population, the fear of people in Croatia. We have to discuss it here, we can't put it under the rug.  Another reason is certainly the schizophrenic situation in which Croatia finds itself. On the one hand, Croatia is called out for the fact that, apparently, not everything was very good when it comes to the treatment of refugees, and on the other hand there is an obligation to protect the border of the European Union. So I think there's a big challenge here for the European Commission as well. Thanks for the help that has been given to Bosnia and Herzegovina so far because it helps, of course, the situation in Croatia, but on the other hand, I think we have to monitor every situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina to the end because we need to help that country. Its institutions are not yet doing everything right, and the problems then relate to the European Union and to us.  Therefore, I call on the Commission to continue to monitor, to continue funding and to really ensure that all those who are in Bosnia and Herzegovina as migrants are treated humanly, but also, on the other hand, that we do not allow illegal migration and immigration to Bosnia and Herzegovina as well.  So I think after everything we've seen, after what we experienced a few years ago, that the migrant wave has calmed down, but it exists it's still going on and it's our obligation to talk about it and take care of it.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán
text: GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, since the European governments decided in 2016 to close the borders of the Balkan route to lime and chant, thousands of people have been trapped in Bosnia and Herzegovina in inhumane conditions. We must denounce how the Croatian authorities are acting at the border. From January to August of this year alone, UNHCR has encrypted hot returns in more than 2,500. Human Rights Watch has reported violence by security forces towards migrants. Six people have died as a result of this violence in recent years; The last one, a six-year-old girl. And activist organizations fighting this with solidarity are being criminalized with police persecution and intimidation. But the most serious thing is that what the Croatian Government is actually doing is in perfect harmony with the European Commission's migration policies. What they are implementing in Croatia is not so different from what is happening at the other external borders of the European Union. For example, in Ceuta and Melilla the situation of violence on fences and hot returns are also being reported by organizations. In Viktor Orbán's Hungary, violence and human rights violations are systematic. And on the great external border, which is the Mediterranean Sea, the European Union's policy is to let them drown. And of course all this is contrary to European legislation. The problem is that, the problem is that the European Union's own political migration project violates its own rules. So the responsibility is for Croatia, Spain, Hungary or Italy, but not alone. It is the European Union's model of border closure, that no one sets foot in Europe, of wanting to deport them all, is the one that shelters these kinds of policies that bring thousands of people to death. It is the model of the European Union. Those responsible are the European Commission, the Member States and also the MEPs who, with their vote, endorse these policies. (She agreed to answer a question posed in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear Chairman, I would respond to my colleague who unfairly calls out Croatia, Croatia who was recently in Marrakech and tried to control and help migration regular flows in a regular way. This is how populist tries to divide Europe.  This is the exact opposite of what can be helped by these poor people who are looking for salvation and who are looking for safety. So don't bring in and don't help populists in this way by accusing Croatia. That's not true.

name: President. –
text: This is less a question than a comment, but, in any case, would you like to listen to the second question and then respond to both of them, or would you like to respond now?

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: 'blue card' response – I am not accusing Croatia, I am accusing all the governments of the European Union and the European Commission of migration policies which are absolutely inhumane and insolidarian. Responsibility is not only for Croatia, Spain or Italy, or any particular country. It's everybody's. Of the whole European Commission, of the Council and, as I said, of the majority of MEPs who here, with their vote, endorse such policies.  (She agreed to answer a question posed in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: the question she asked by raising the blue card. – Dear Chairman, I have a question for Mrs. Guzmán, following her presentation and activism over the past few months on this topic.  I have a question for you. Do you use this topic for your personal promotion and do you use the fates of these sad, poor migrants for your personal promotion?  When it comes to Croatia, Croatia is implementing all measures that are anti-criminal, which the Austrian Presidency strongly presented, and this is why the Croatian police behave in accordance with all possible regulations and international rules, taking into account, of course, human rights.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" response. – I cannot accuse someone of populist or trying to win votes on the issue of immigration, when in a debate on the situation of migrants he talks about crime. That's populism. What's more, that's much more than populism. That's a far right. Talking about crime and migration all together in the same debate is what is giving wings to racist and xenophobic stances.

name: Bodil Valero
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to begin by saying that I very much agree with what the previous speaker said in this House. It is very much about European policy in general. There I feel that we are talking much more about numbers than about people. We have somehow dehumanised the whole migration debate. These are people who come to us for various reasons to seek protection, but we talk about them as if they were numbers in a statistic. That is the big problem for all of us, I would say. We are in the situation we are today, because not all countries have taken joint responsibility for those who have come to us. Some countries have completely refused to accept migrants. Other countries, such as my own Sweden, have received an enormous number. We have to do this together and then we can also have a humane, humane migration policy where we do not see people as numbers, which I see as the major problem. If we are then to start from what has happened, or the subject we are talking about today, precisely the border in Bosnia and Herzegovina, then I think it is a good thing, as the Commissioner said, that we need to investigate properly what has happened. It goes without saying that our EU countries must comply with the regulations that we have and that means that if a person enters Croatia or any other country, that person has the right to seek asylum there. That person cannot just be returned to another country. Regardless of whether you have bilateral readmission agreements with that country, that person has the right to seek asylum. That person should not be abused, should not be humiliated, should not be robbed, but that person should be allowed to seek refuge in the country you have come to. The Union shall be based on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights. That's what we're all going to do.

name: Bill Etheridge
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I’d like to start off, particularly at this time of year, by saying that we should all wish well to all people, especially those in difficulty: refugees, asylum seekers, those who may not be able to sleep comfortably in their beds at night. Particularly at a festive time of year like Christmas, it’s beholden on us to remember that. However, this is an interesting debate because, in the UK, it’s very much framed as the EU being all about economics and trade, especially at the moment that’s the main thing. But we see, at the moment, a very real situation still going on in relation to migration and the issues around borders, and there is talk about EU security and border controls being put into nations, and money being spent on, or thrown at, this. I cannot help but believe in my heart that, actually, when you look at immigration into independent countries, individual sovereign states, they would be better being given control of their own borders to look after these things themselves, and if they need help, there is such a thing as a foreign aid budget. The UK has an enormous foreign aid budget – we’re often classed as a foreign aid superpower – and yet, again, we are contributing twice, as EU funding is going into this as well. Surely it would be better to give individual sovereign states the right to control their borders and, if they need assistance, if there is a crisis, to address it by means of other states offering foreign aid.

name: Mario Borghezio
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, while this debate is taking place, not far away, at the Hôpital Hautpierre, together with others, a 28-year-old Italian boy, Antonio Megaliti, is struggling with death. I would like to address a thought to this victim of Islamist terrorism. It is perfectly in tune with the subject I want to address, because behind this development of migrants can hide the smokescreen of the presence of many former warriors of Allah who have been defeated in the Islamic State and who penetrate, together with the migrants, into Bosnia and Herzegovina. I would like to remind you of what a Bosnian journalist denounces in a recent interview, namely that there is a danger that these people, by entering, will come into contact with young Bosnian Muslims and convert them, radicalize them. This must be the commitment of the European Union, which has heavily financed Bosnia and Herzegovina to carry out real deradicalisation, not in words, by fighting against those who agonise young Muslims and radicalise them for actions such as those that have marred this week – Islamist terrorism that some, hypocritical and cowardly, do not have the courage to call by their name: Islamic terrorism!

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the number of refugee and migrant arrivals in Bosnia and Herzegovina during 2018 has increased significantly, with more than 22,400 arrivals since the beginning of the year and compared to 755 in 2017.  Many attempt to move through Bosnia and Herzegovina to join the Union, crossing Croatia. However, others remain in the country. UNHCR estimates that around 6,000 people were present in Bosnianherzego territory in mid-November 2018. Local communities and international organizations have taken care of basic care: food, shelter, primary health care. However, the country's capabilities are overwhelmed. Since June, the Union has mobilisation more than EUR 9.2 million between immediate aid and medium-term aid. This facilitates, but is not limited to, access to essential services that are far from migration routes.  The Western Balkans itinerary is mainly used by Afghans, Pakistanis and Syrians. Throughout 2018, migration pressure on this route has been increasing, leading to organized crime groups increasing their criminal activity around human trafficking. This is one of the main reasons why Europol has identified this region as a priority in increasing cooperation.  Our Charter of Fundamental Rights, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the 1951 Convention on the Status of Refugees and the 1967 Protocol commit us. And they commit us, fundamentally, from a humanitarian point of view. I applaud the States that signed the Global Compact on Migration in Marrakesh. All this, to the European Union as a human rights defender, is unequivocally committed.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the With this question to the Commission, we want to shed light on what is happening in Bosnia-Herzegovina, which are indeed worrying.  Thousands of people have been on the run in the region since the symbolic closure of the Balkan route. Forgotten by the European public, they live in catastrophic circumstances. Time and again there are desperate attempts to escape this situation. This gives a boost, above all, to the criminal people smugglers. There are always incidents at the external borders that need to be investigated. I have made the death of a girl, Medina Hussiny, the subject of a question. We need clarity as to what is really going on, how large the number of people affected is, what resources are being used and how they are being used and, above all, how to solve the problems. It would be wrong to think that the problems can be solved by looking away. Such an extremely short-term approach has already led to disastrous consequences in 2015. The Commission is called upon to learn from its mistakes at the time.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the This discussion shows once again that some speakers are trying to undermine the sovereignty of the EU Member States with humanitarian aspects. And sovereignty means that borders are secured. It really is not a new realization that a large proportion of the migrants are so-called economic migrants, that is, they are not politically persecuted, but they are looking for a better world. That is permissible, but the countries of the EU cannot accept people indefinitely and even unchecked. We can see what problems this is already causing. And I really must also tell you, Mrs Guzman of the GUE: you have tried here in what I think is an outrageous way to immediately spread a halo on all migrants, according to the motto: if someone says, yes, they also commit crimes – that cannot be the case. It is quite clear that not every migrant is a criminal. Whoever says that is stupid. But, conversely, migrants are, of course, also committing crimes, and that is why we must control the borders.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Bosnia and Herzegovina has until now been mainly an emigration country, with young people leaving. Now the situation has changed: we have a lot of people, 23 000 this year, coming through the country, seeing it as a transit country, wanting to go to the EU but then getting stuck at the border. The facilities and the possibilities of the country to deal with this situation are very limited. The country has only two asylum centres and has been improvising by using abandoned factories, but I’m sorry to say there are migrants who are sleeping outside in temperatures of below zero, so the conditions are very difficult and the days are getting colder. The country has neither the financial nor the administrative resources to deal with this situation and we have an obligation to help. So far the citizens have been helping. The country has done a decent job in handling this situation, given that they had never been in this situation previously. The border situation is critical. There has been violence at the Croatian border. I’ve received reports from the ground and I’ve received reports from Human Rights Watch saying they have seen this, that the police are using force and violence against migrants, pushing them back to Bosnia. This inhuman behaviour should be stopped and investigated, as the Commissioner said. I am very grateful for the help the Commission has offered. I think it should be increased and we, as partners of Bosnia, need to provide administrative support to give them any hope of coping with this situation. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Not forgetting that our Lord was a refugee, at this time of year one doesn’t want to be cruel to people who are suffering or whatever. But the only problem is, if we give more funds and help people even more, it will encourage more refugees or financial people, people looking for a better life. I don’t blame them: if I were in their situation I’d want to come west too, but the trouble is we can’t afford it, our people have got enough trouble getting jobs themselves, it is causing a lot of trouble. Would you not agree with me that to continue to dish out money is simply going to encourage more people to try and come?

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – I totally disagree with you because giving the country monetary and administrative help to cope with the situation doesn’t mean anything to migrants, they don’t know about it. So this will be neither good nor bad for them: they will not come because of it, they will not refrain from coming because of it, it will just help the countries to deal with the situation in a decent human away, and it is our obligation to do that.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF).
text: Mr President, the rigours of the Balkan winter cannot obscure a reality now so undeniable that even the coordinator of the International Organization for Migration in Sarajevo reluctantly acknowledged that 85% of the pseudo-refugees stationed in Bosnia and Herzegovina are in fact economic migrants, demonstrating that, in the face of this migratory surge, denial is no longer even a recipe.  Especially since this new Balkan route is largely successful: three quarters of the migrants transiting through Bosnia and Herzegovina would manage to leave it, free to go as they see fit in Europe. They will never be deported.  Who's to blame? To the European Union, of course. Satisfied to pour millions in sheer loss into the barrel of the Danaïdes of the migrant crisis when, in truth, the only ones we need to support are the Croatian security forces and the Bosnian Serbs represented by Milorad Dodik, who is courageously fighting against a real submersion against which all now seem to have capitulated.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is an area of freedom and security which must be based on full respect for fundamental rights. The reports coming from the border between Croatia and Bosnia are therefore worrying. It is true that each Member State determines who or does not enter its territory, but in an area of freedom of movement the external borders of each State actually become common external borders. That is why we share a set of rules on how we carry out border controls, the so-called Schengen rules, how we look at asylum applications and even how we return people. However, we must clearly condemn the violation of those rules, but we also have to come up with solutions, and that is why I call on the European Commission to make use of the Schengen evaluation mechanism in order to be able to identify and recommend solutions as a matter of urgency. This does not mean favouring an open-door policy; it simply means that everything is not worth in border control, let alone called into question the basic principles of humanity. We are facing another symptom of this major disease which is the inaction of the Member States, their inability to accept reforms that this Parliament has long advocated. We need an effective return policy, a functioning common European asylum system with a strengthened European agency and a robust and effective border agency. Once again, Mr. President, they pay the most vulnerable for the weaknesses of the strongest.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Mr. Chairman, Croatia in 2018 is faced with a sharp increase in irregular border crossings, primarily from neighbouring Bosnia and Herzegovina. This is an increase of as much as 57% compared to the previous year. I would like to remind you that Croatia has the longest external land border of the European Union, and in protecting this border it does not follow the examples of its EU neighbours, which protect their borders with barbed wire.  There are currently about 6,500 migrants on the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina, most of them in makeshift accommodation near the Croatian border, which increases the possibility of attempted irregular crossings. As a member who expects to join Schengen as soon as possible, Croatia is aware that migration is a global challenge and has supported the Global Compact in Marrakech. The Union has the right to expect all members and potential members to respect fundamental human rights, investigate and prosecute those responsible for their violations. At the same time, the Union has an obligation to help more strongly countries with limited resources at such a long border face the local echo of one major European problem.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Dear Mr President, honourable Members, the Republic of Croatia has every reason and every right to defend its borders. Let's not forget that the Republic of Croatia is an external border for the European Union and protects the citizens of the European Union. So the Republic of Croatia cannot be blamed for guarding its borders. Let's not encourage crime. Illegal, illegal crossing of a border is a crime, not a violation. It cannot be justified and cannot be encouraged. Each border must be crossed at the legal state checkpoints. In this regard, any conversation that promotes illegal migration works against the security of European citizens. Any conversation that justifies breaking the law works against the security of European citizens. Illegal immigration, dear colleagues, is not a right, it is not a human right. And for the protection of the rights, freedoms, health of all European citizens, every country is obliged. (The Speaker agrees to answer a question asked by raising a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: "blue card" question. – I would like to ask Mr Dzhambazki a question about this insistent reference to encouraging illegal immigration. Is there anyone who wants illegal immigration in Europe? Because it seems that some say that it is like others, those of us who insist that human rights be respected, that the funds of the European Union , which are those of all Europeans – are used appropriately to ensure that international law is complied with, so that borders are properly ordered, so that the agreements we have, including that of the reception of refugees, are respected. Who wants illegal immigration to Europe, Mr. Dzhambazki?

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – Thank you for your question, dear colleague. Many colleagues in this chamber even encourage illegal migration and justify it. There are fellow European representatives in this Chamber who openly advocate illegal migration, encourage it and encourage it. And that's harmful. And this is directed against the security of European citizens. And this is directed against the social systems of European citizens. The false thesis that illegal migration is a right is a false thesis.

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: – Dear Chairman, Mr. Commissioner, colleagues and colleagues, Croatia is in a situation where neighbouring countries have opened borders on the incoming route, do not want or cannot control the influx of refugees, and neighbouring countries on the outgoing route, european Union member states have closed their borders with barbed wire. So it's a very difficult situation.  We have set high principles in international conventions on respect for rights, including migrants' rights and children's rights, and we have not created legal assumptions either at European or national level, nor have we developed policies to respect these high international principles and that is why we are in this situation that we find ourselves in.  Mr. Commissioner spoke about this, about the Ombudsperson's report, but this report states that the application of the principle of solidarity in refugee relocation in the European Union is respected incompletely and that this principle is disputed because it is not respected. Likewise, the Court of Justice of the European Union has ruled that allowing refugees to enter and transfer refugees through countries is in fact a violation of the Dublin Regulation.  So these are the questions that need to be asked. Thus, more solidarity and assistance to countries facing refugees, both those who are members and those who are not members of the European Union.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Mr. Chairman, at the very beginning I thank croatian police officers for the extremely demanding work they do very professionally protecting the external border of the European Union from illegal crossings, thereby keeping Croatian and European citizens safe. This year, more than 22,000 refugees, asylum seekers and migrants have arrived in Bosnia and Herzegovina, of which about 4,000 have expressed the need for humanitarian assistance. In 2018, the European Union allocated €2 million for their accommodation, while it has allocated €31 million for humanitarian aid over the past three years for the Western Balkans. At the moment, the most important thing is to help the authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina and humanitarian associations so that they can help those in need. The scope of union assistance should also be extended to assist the administration of Bosnia and Herzegovina in resolving asylum applications as quickly as possible, but also to return as quickly as possible to the home countries of all those who do not qualify for asylum. Bosnia and Herzegovina also needs to use European Union funds to make progress in the fight against radicalisation and extremism, which is on the rise in the country. Coexistence and tolerance have always been lived on the territory of BiH, and today, unfortunately, some other values that are a threat to security throughout the region are promoted. The flow of money for radicalisation needs to be stopped, as well as the spread of radicalisation itself so that the tragic events we have witnessed in France, Germany and Belgium do not occur.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after the closure of the Hungarian border, it was easy to imagine that the Balkan route would move. Last summer, the situation on the Bosnian-Croatian border worsened and serious human rights violations and shortcomings in the right to apply for asylum were already reported. With the winter, the situation is only getting worse: migrants and refugees are constantly being pushed back to the border, victims of a cruel game between traffickers and border police. There are at least 5 000 lives tested in this border area, including harassment, cold, severe malnutrition, sanitary and sanitary conditions below humanitarian standards. The life of every human being is sacred and must be respected. I am proud that a few days ago, in Marrakech, our Delegation of the European Parliament gave its full support to the adoption of the global compact for migration. I believe that this must also be taken into account in our work. We cannot let Croatia and Bosnia manage this clear emergency on their own. I would remind you that, at the beginning of the year, some 23 000 people entered Bosnia, dreaming of Europe. Human rights cannot be stopped by borders, they are an integral part of every man, woman and child, and I am proud to be able to repeat them in this House, the seat of democracy. The humanity we share must be the cornerstone of our work, a commitment to the common good and to the protection of every human being.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as permanent rapporteur for Bosnia, of course I have watched what is happening in this country with regard to migrants. I met Minister Mektić a few months ago and encouraged him over the period to manage the situation. Of course, at this moment, when winter came, the situation of the migrants in question is delicate. This problem of migrants from Croatia is added and there are attempts to politicise the issue. I also saw a colleague here from the right-wing extremist group, saying that the rescue would come from Putin's man in Bosnia and Herzegovina, from the recently elected President Dodik. I think we need to help Croatia, as we have already done – the Commission has sent a lot of money there – and calm the too-heated spirits of politicians a little.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, I hope to be well translated this time. As the rapporteur for Bosnia and Herzegovina Mr. Preda said, the politicisation of the refugee issue is in force in Bosnia and Herzegovina.  We have a problem of functioning government, money is not a problem, money exists, but refugees agree on the border with the European Union, on the border with Croatia. Croatia has an obligation to keep its borders safe, to protect the security of the European Union and Croatia absolutely respects all international conventions and in this case I call on the authorities in Sarajevo to finally take it seriously, together with the international community, and solve this problem where it started, at its source.  There is money, and refugees cannot be sent to borders with the European Union and transfer the security problem to the security problem of the Republic of Croatia.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I will leave what you said: the difficult situation for the local population. I believe that we should not rush to blame neither Bosnia and Herzegovina nor Croatia. I believe that the European institutions must think that they have not regulated, but above all, that everything we are talking about migration and asylum procedures does not apply very well. We must not forget that, almost every day, terrorist attacks happen. Behold, I have lived this these days. Are the states ready? Why, for so many days, have they not been able to catch him? Hundreds and thousands of even members of the police force failed to catch an attacker. So I think it is very important to have a very rigorous analysis on the agenda: how migration, asylum, is applied in practice, in order to protect the European population and, of course, to respect human rights as well. But here, we are not talking about legal migration, people fleeing the war zone, but we are talking about economic migration, which is totally unsupervised.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, it has been said by colleagues that there is a real problem on Bosnia's border with Croatia. You said there were five and a half thousand refugees crowding in. So imagine what a problem there is on the island of Samos, where there are currently six thousand refugees and illegal immigrants on one island alone. But I didn't hear any suggestions. I haven't heard any solutions. Just greetings.  Question one: How have these thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants arrived in Bosnia? In what way? Did they come from other countries? You said they came from Turkey. But how did they get to Bosnia? Is there an air connection to Turkish Airlines? Who has the responsibilities of getting these people there? That's what we need to look for. Secondly, there are certainly obligations of Bosnia, because it also has an association agreement with the European Union. As for Croatia, a colleague told Croatia to enter Schengen. I am telling you that if Croatia enters Schengen, you will be a magnet for more refugees and illegal immigrants, as is the case with Greece.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, shame on those Members on the far right who are exploiting the tragedy that happened here in Strasbourg on Tuesday night, using it to express their racist and Islamophobic views! Migration is an ongoing human phenomenon. When life is unsustainable because of war, famine, poverty, climate change and so on, people will move. We are all part of the problem and we need to fix it together in a humane way. My friend Danica Jurisic is a Bosnian refugee from the Balkans war. She knows what it means to lose everything, to suffer dispossession. And what is she doing? Well, she’s helping the refugees and migrants back in her home country and she’s also helping them here in her adopted home in France. She is the person on the ground in Paris working, with Care4Calais, with all the refugees and migrants who were displaced from ‘the jungle’. And I want to urge all the Members here to support the ‘winter coats for Calais’ campaign. Do something!

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased that the Commission is finally here to talk about the situation on the border between Bosnia and Croatia. Three months ago, together with 20 colleagues, we asked the Commission whether it was monitoring the desperate situation of thousands of people in Bihać, Velika Kladuša, who were left to their own devices in unacceptable conditions. Two days ago, human rights watch's statements confirmed what has been reported in recent months by many international newspapers and associations working on the ground. Is the Commission aware of the systematic violence by the Croatian authorities, against which there have been numerous accusations, and if so, what does it intend to do to monitor the situation, to investigate these allegations and to give an answer that is respectful of people's fundamental rights? We are also asking for answers on brutal rejections: let us remember that these people have the right to seek asylum in Europe, in Croatia, when they are on Croatian territory. We are also calling for independent monitoring of what is happening, because it is incredible that your inability to accept in internal solidarity is making other countries pay for it and on the skin of these people! Thanks to the volunteers who make up for your shortcomings.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for a very interesting and controversial debate – very controversial! First of all, let me tell you that I disagree with those who are blaming the Commission. Absolutely. Of course, we all are responsible, of that there is no doubt, and we know very well that we need to do more. But don’t blame each other, don’t blame the Commission, because we are deeply involved in this – the Commission is dealing every day with the issues and we are aware of the many problems. The European Union responded promptly to the situation: humanitarian funding amounting to EUR 2 million was allocated to the emergency needs of refugees and migrants present in Bosnia and Herzegovina. This assistance is channelled through humanitarian partners, such as United Nations agencies, and covers the provision of food, clothing, blankets, hygiene items, health services, protection and emergency shelters. Of course, we know very well that there is a dangerous situation now due to the climate in winter time. The Commission has allocated up to EUR 7.2 million to increase the capacity for identification, registration and protection of migrants, to support the Bosnia and Herzegovina border police and to provide adequate accommodation for the winter period. It has continued providing significant support to Bosnia and Herzegovina, including to the municipalities affected by the current migration flows. This recent support is in addition to the EUR 24.6 million that the EU has granted since 2007 to Bosnia and Herzegovina in the area of migration and border management. Let me assure you that the Commission is in contact with the Croatian Government concerning the implementation of the European asylum procedure rules, including with regard to allegations of misinformation or of denying non-EU nationals the possibility of applying for asylum. We need to continue that investigation. While the Commission will continue to monitor this situation we trust that Croatia will follow up on the specific allegations and will continue to cooperate closely with Bosnia and Herzegovina. At the same time, the Commission would point out that Bosnia and Herzegovina needs to step up its efforts in effectively coordinating the response and enhancing the implementation of its own asylum procedures. And Croatia needs to support the Bosnia and Herzegovina Government in strengthening its capacity to solve the problem. Finally, let me underscore the importance of mutual coordination, and assure you that the Commission is making serious efforts to avoid a deterioration of the situation on the ground. We are doing what we can.

name: Președintele. –
text: The debate has been closed.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Iran, in particular the case of Nasrin Sotoudeh (2018/2967(RSP)).

name: Heidi Hautala
text: author. – Mr President, we are talking here about Nasrin Sotoudeh and notably the case of her persecution. She’s a brave human rights lawyer and she has been detained and convicted because of her work defending human rights in Iran. Notably, she was defending the rights of women not to be obliged to wear the veil. I believe that Iran cannot have a bright future without the empowerment of women, and that’s what so many women activists are now trying to do in Iran, to show that the women are an important force in the country. So what we are calling for is an immediate and unconditional release of Nasrin Sotoudeh. Nasrin Sotoudeh is also the 2012 Sakharov Prize winner, so we have a special duty to follow her life and her work, and whenever Sakharov Prize winners are under persecution, we react. We use diplomatic channels but it’s time also now to express our view and our concern, and our demand in public here in the European Parliament today. We demand also that the delegation in Iran representing the European Union and its Member States follow her case, visit the prison and convey our demand to release her immediately and unconditionally. Also this resolution is very much about the recent concerns about the living conditions of people in Iran. We want to express our solidarity for those who suffer from drought and worsening living conditions, and I think it’s our right to express our solidarity to these people. Finally, we should be aware of the damaging impact of the United States’ sanctions on the people of Iran.

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. – Mr President, I’m pleased that we are today raising the case of Nasrin Sotoudeh, a Sakharov laureate and prominent human rights lawyer in Iran. The harassment of lawyers and human rights activists in this manner is wholly unacceptable and is illustrative of the fundamental lack of basic civil rights that exists within Iran under the theocratic regime. I naturally support the calls for her immediate release, but we should remember that her case is by no means an isolated one. I’m one of those that strongly supports the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) but I’ve always maintained, as is key to that nuclear deal, that this should not mean we shy away from highlighting the dire human rights situations that persist in Iran and have been there for many years. This resolution also raises the important issue of dual nationals who have been arrested and detained in Iran, including many EU citizens. The case of Nazanin Zaghari—Ratcliffe continues to dominate UK—Iran relations and I call, once again, for her release, I sincerely hope in time to return to her family in England for Christmas.

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I would like to make three points here. The first is that we are showing solidarity, without any ifs and buts, with all the people of Iran who are demonstrating against social and economic grievances, against corruption and mismanagement, because their living conditions have become intolerable – with the truck drivers who are not paid, with the environmental activists who are fighting against climate damage. And I also say that no one should be imprisoned simply because he is demonstrating, and nowhere, by the way, anywhere. Just because they are protesting, being thrown in jail and persecuted is unacceptable. Secondly, we are calling for the immediate release of Nasrin Sotoudeh and her husband – Nasrin Sotoudeh, a courageous lawyer, it must also be said, who has remained in Iran, representing women who are fighting for their freedom. For me, it is incomprehensible that a Sakharov Prize winner should be thrown in jail and that we are then expected to support the Iranians. But we also support those women who are now in prison simply because they have chosen not to wear a headscarf. Man is born free, and he shall remain so, and he shall also freely decide over himself. That is a minimum of what we have to ask for here. And the third is: yes, we stand behind the JCPOA, because we do not want a nuclear arms race anywhere, and because it is a damn time to finally free ourselves from the patronage of an irresponsible US president who behaves like Emperor Nero. Europe needs an independent policy towards the Middle East. It is time to do so now, and it also calls for a rebellion against US sanctions.

name: Ana Gomes
text: author. – Mr President, the lawyer Nasrin Sotoudeh was in jail when we awarded her the 2012 Sakharov Prize and she was never able to come to meet us because she has now been thrown in jail for several years in Iran for her indefatigable advocacy for human rights and women’s rights. Her husband, Reza Khandan, because he dared to protest publicly against her imprisonment, was also arrested and accused of spreading propaganda against the regime and promoting the practice of appearing in public without a veil. Such ridiculous charges tell us everything about the tragedy in which Iran is ensnared. On the one hand, a vibrant people, proud of its civilisation and full of potential; on the other, an archaic regime that needs to impose brutal repression on the people. The new law on drugs has been positive, sparing the death penalty for thousands of Iranian citizens. But torture, unfair trials, the discrimination of minorities and religious persecution... all of that compounds the terrible repressive framework against which the citizens of Iran increasingly bravely resist and denounce. When I returned to Iran last February in a delegation of the European Parliament, I could sense the people were much more vocal, and therefore we call for the release of all the political prisoners, all the human rights campaigners like Nasrin Sotoudeh. The more we feel attached to the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), which is also about human rights, the more we need to raise human rights and indeed demand that this action ends.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: author. – Mr President, Commissioner and colleagues, human rights lawyer Nasrin Sotoudeh is one of the world’s most courageous human rights defenders. Herself and her family are paying an extraordinary price for her doing her job. I’m very proud that we awarded her the Sakharov Prize but that also gives us specific responsibility to speak out for her freedom. The Islamic Republic has once again shown its true colours by imprisoning Nasrin Sotoudeh – again. This time, because she defended courageous women – the courageous women who want the freedom to wear or not to wear the hijab, and it is essential that High Representative Mogherini speaks out both publicly and privately in her many engagements with representatives of the Islamic Republic of Iran. She must speak out for the universal human rights of all Iranians, but especially for the human rights defenders and the women that have a legitimate and modest claim when they want not to be forced to wear a religious symbol.

name: Tunne Kelam
text: author. – Mr President, I think it’s symbolic for the existing human rights situation in Iran that even a prominent human rights defender and receiver of the Sakharov Prize six years ago, Nasrin Sotoudeh, has been kept in custody now for more than half a year for publicly opposing Iranian compulsory hijab law. This is happening against the background of countrywide popular protests, which have continued throughout 2018. I can only quote Amnesty International’s latest report seven days ago, which says: ‘Iran is in the grip of a multifaceted crisis that is rooted in the confluence of severe political, economic, environmental and human rights problems. [...] In response, the authorities have been widening the net of repressions.’ It is not any more about small groups of protesters, but about widespread strikes by truck drivers, teachers, environmental activists, workers, students and national and religious minorities, who stand up against the dramatically worsening economic and social conditions, against corruption and political repressions. We demand therefore, first and foremost, the immediate release of Nasrin Sotoudeh. However, just appealing and asking will not be enough. To have a real impact on the behaviour of Iranian rulers, the European Commission and Member States’ governments need to implement unanimously and forcefully the recipe the European Parliament formulated a long time ago. The recipe of resolution stresses once more today that any progress in economic and political relations should be strictly conditional on a credible improvement of the human rights situation, citizens’ rights and freedom of expression. Nothing less.  The EU can make a difference, provided we can strike a principle link between realpolitik and universal values.

name: Michaela Šojdrová
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, this summer another human rights defender in the Middle East, lawyer Nasrin Sotoude, was imprisoned in Iran. Her case is unique both in that she is the first woman in the order of imprisoned lawyers in Iran, and also in the fact that she is a political prisoner who was not afraid to go on hunger strike in protest. Last but not least, she is also the winner of the Sakharov Prize, which she received from the European Parliament in 2012. Nasrin Sotoudo is fighting for gender equality, for the rights of ethnic and religious minorities, which are not guaranteed in Iran. We must not be all the more indifferent to its fate, because the death penalty continues to be applied in Iran, including against political prisoners. The European Parliament has repeatedly raised its voice and demanded freedom for Nasrin and other political prisoners. I appreciate that we agree on this across the political spectrum, that is our strength, and that is the hope for political prisoners.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Nasrin Sotoudeh received the Sakharov Prize in 2012. At the time, she was also in prison. One of the first measures taken by The new President Rouhani the following year was to release them, and this was generally seen at the time as a first positive sign of the Iranian leadership's willingness to talk about the human rights situation in the country. In Parliament's delegation, of which I was a member at the time, I was able to meet her in Tehran at the time, where she impressed us with her constructive manner. Her detention is shocking to all of us, it is a wake-up call. We call on Iran to take the human rights dialogue seriously and to do everything possible to make progress here. This also applies to the situation of people with dual citizenship, as in the case of Kamran Ghaderi. And we expect the immediate release of Nasrin Sotoudeh. It is also high time that she and Jafar Panahi were finally able to receive the Sakharov Prize, which was awarded to them six years ago, here in Strasbourg.

name: Bas Belder
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the Islamic Republic of Iran remains an intriguing country. Today, for example, national clergy are deeply concerned about the erosion of their public status. This process undermines the legitimacy of the regime. In this threatening situation, human rights must be severely deretributated. Our resolution speaks clearly about this. The brutal persecution of human rights lawyer Nasrin Sotoudeh is illustrative.  I am also very concerned about the wave of arrests of Christians in Iran: 142 believers last month, more than 100 in the first week of December. That is why I call on the Council and the Commission, in contacts with the Iranian authorities, to raise this unprecedented barbaric persecution of Christians. I would, of course, like to hear the results of this European commitment to the fundamental right of freedom of faith in the Islamic Republic of Iran.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, the West is living in a feminist moment. A moment of nonconformism with the inequality that women suffer. But our problems shouldn't blind us to what's going on elsewhere. In Iran, when a woman takes off her hijab, she is holding a political protest. It's a heroic act, because they know they can end up in jail, but not just them. Nasrín Sotudé, our 2012 Sakharov Award, is a human rights lawyer in Iran and has been imprisoned again. This time, for defending the women who took off their hijab in public.  If we truly believe in freedom and equality, we will do everything in our power for Nasrín's liberation. If we truly believe in human rights, we will work to clarify the tens of thousands of executions and disappearances carried out by the Iranian regime since the 1980s.  The feminist cause and the humanitarian cause are universal. Human rights are the rights of human beings, of all human beings. Europe is certainly called to lead them and must do so.

name: Margot Parker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, nothing is more intimate to a person then their religious belief. To express a belief or lack of in God or a higher power is a fundamental right that too few people around the world truly enjoy. For some women the hijab is a vital expression of their faith, for others it is an oppressive tool. What is consistent is that it should be a woman’s right to choose what they wear and how they express themselves. That the women of Iran cannot do so, not only out of social pressure but through the power of the State and law, is a gross violation of human decency. Iran must listen to her citizens, roll back these oppressive laws and allow their citizens to choose.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I join in the call for the immediate release of Nasrin Sotoudeh and the other human rights defenders, who have been detained for the sole reason that they have exercised their right to expression and thought. I am extremely concerned about the deterioration of human rights in Iran and believe that, in the dialogue with the European External Action Service, it is necessary to continue to raise this issue on all possible occasions. I stress that I believe it is crucial that the Iran nuclear agreement remains alive. Trump's decision to withdraw from the agreements and impose new sanctions hurts Iran economically but also from the point of view of the situation of internal freedoms. Sanctions and the reduction of international cooperation can only have a profound negative impact on civil and social rights, as well as on economic rights in Iran. An EU delegation must be set up in Iran for dialogue and increased cooperation with iran in the various areas of interest to both sides, with full respect for human rights.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Mr. Chairman, over the past months we have witnessed numerous arrests of activists and protesters against the Iranian regime. Executions continue to take place in Iran, with political prisoners among those executed. In addition to human rights activists, the Iranian regime also arrests women and lawyers specializing in human rights, such as the arrests of Reza Khandan and Nasrin Sotoudeh. Political prisoners are currently on hunger strike, and their mental and physical condition is unknown. Christians and other religious minorities are also being persecuted in Iran. I also express concern about the Continued work of the Iranian regime on the nuclear missile programme, which is a major international threat to peace. I am interested, Mr. Commissioner, how is the dialogue with the Iranian authorities progressing regarding stopping executions and preventing violence against political prisoners, human rights activists, women and Christians in Iran?

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we awarded the Sakharov prize to Oleg Sentsov yesterday, but four laureates are still imprisoned, including Nasrin Sotoudeh. She is the Iranian women’s rights defender who has been shamefully attacked by the government for her outstanding work.  There is an urgent need for the different EU institutions to create meaningful cooperation to support human rights defenders that have been awarded the Sakharov Prize. They’re part of our family. Thanks to the ProtectDefenders.eu mechanism, the EU has become one of the strongest supporters of human rights defenders’ safety in the world, and as Members of the European Parliament, it is our duty to closely follow the situation of the laureates of the Sakharov Prize. I therefore call on the Iranian authorities to immediately and unconditionally to release Nasrin and drop all charges against her.  I also join the call of my fellow British MEP, Charles Tannock, to ask the Iranian authorities to release Nazanin Zakaria Ratcliffe, the mother and charity worker wrongfully imprisoned in September 2016.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Mr President, I would like to take this opportunity to speak on a subject close to my heart. I would like to start by saying that, of course, I understand the condemnation, especially for human rights, but I would always like to remind you that we must not apply double standards. I am also thinking of persecuted Christians in China, Turkey, Algeria and many other countries. So we have to be careful to avoid double standards. On the other hand, I would like to add that Iran is a great civilization, which has been attacked several times, beyond the mullah regime. I can even understand, because it was the policy of my country, France, that Iran wanted to have nuclear power, because that is how France was able to maintain its independence, its neutrality, its sovereignty. I also fully understand the policy of Israel and the United States and, as a friend of Israel, of course, I also support it. Now is the time for Europe to really play this balance between the different powers.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, yesterday this European Parliament presented its Sakharov Prize for this edition this year. But in 2012 Nasrín Sotudé obtained it, a lawyer defending the cause of human rights in a context of enormous difficulty: Iran ruled by supreme leader Ali Khamenei, to which the Institute of Human Rights of the International Bar Association has addressed in 2018 a letter requiring the immediate release of Nasrín Sotudé, who has been imprisoned on several occasions for defending just causes of freedom of expression and above all the rights of Women. As a former minister of justice and as a former chairman of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and always committed to the right to defence, to advocacy and in particular to this woman, who defends the right of women to free themselves from the hijab in a hugely repressive context, we demand Iran's immediate release.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we believe that the best way to advance human rights worldwide is through diplomatic pressure and direct engagement with the relevant authorities. This has always been our approach to human rights violations with Iran. The High Representative and all of us raise the issue in all of our meetings with the Iranian authorities at all levels. No one is as engaged as the European Union against the death penalty in Iran, against all restrictions of fundamental rights and on the side of Iranian human rights defenders. For many years now, we have been closely following the case of Sakharov prize winner Nasrin Sotoudeh and her husband, Reza Khandan. When Ms Sotoudeh was awarded the Sakharov prize in 2012, it was for her work to provide legal representation to human rights defenders, juvenile offenders facing the death penalty and women. As a result of these efforts, she has been harassed, her work impeded, and in 2010 she was sentenced to three years of imprisonment after being convicted of security-related charges. Following her release in 2013, Ms Sotoudeh’s engagement to promote human rights continued and she was again detained in June this year. Her husband, who had been campaigning for her release, was himself detained in September.  Since her detention, the European Union has repeatedly raised Ms Sotoudeh’s case with the Iranian authorities at all levels, including in the framework of the EU-Iran high-level dialogue. At every occasion we express our concerns about the situation of human rights in Iran and the treatment of Iranian human rights defenders. Member States have also raised the case during their own bilateral contacts with the Iranian authorities.  This engagement has recently contributed to certain positive developments. Just one year ago, Iran decided to amend its anti-narcotics legislation and this has resulted in a dramatic reduction in drug-related executions. We are continuing to advocate for further improvements in this regard, including an immediate moratorium on the execution of juvenile offenders.  We continue to call for the release of Ms Sotoudeh and her husband. They should be guaranteed timely access to a lawyer of their own choosing. They should be allowed to communicate with their two children and they should not be subject to any form of mistreatment.  Let me conclude by thanking you for your attention to this case. We will continue to work together with you and engage with the Iranian authorities in order to secure the release of Ms Sotoudeh and her husband.

name: Președintele. –
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debates.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Egypt, in particular the situation of human rights defenders (2018/2968(RSP)).

name: Jordi Solé
text: author. – Mr President, this compromise resolution, which will enjoy large support in the House, is very clear on two fronts. First, it’s the strongest condemnation to date by Parliament of the horrible, terrible human rights situation in Egypt. Secondly, it calls on the EU, in a very clear way, to step up its response and to prioritise the situation of human rights defenders in its dialogue with Egypt. Parliament is saying loud and clear: no more EU ‘business as usual’ with a regime that has wiped out its entire human rights community. Taking up a proposal from my Group, the motion calls on the EU to envisage targeted sanctions against individuals for their responsibility in the current repression. We will be carefully monitoring the EU-Egypt Association Council in a few days and we expect concrete action on the release of the individual human rights defenders listed in the motion.

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. – Mr President, I have been a strong friend of Egypt, I have sought to support the stabilising of efforts made by President al—Sisi’s Government over the past few years and I am all too aware of the very difficult security situation that exists in that fragile country. There can be no doubt that Egypt is facing a persistent and clear danger from terrorism. However, we cannot allow this to be an excuse for ever-more stringent restrictions on its people’s basic civil and human rights. I am very concerned about the increasing threats to freedom of the media and about the arrests and disappearance of journalists. The reported executions of almost 1 500 people during the past four years are also a deeply disturbing trend, particularly given that the vast majority of those concerned were tried in mass trials. As we have learned in Europe, there is a constant tug between implementing meaningful counterterrorism measures and securing people’s basic freedoms. I’m sad to say that the balance in Egypt is now deeply questionable. A change of approach is sorely needed and it is one that the European Union must press for strongly.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. Mr President, i would like to thank the Commissioner for his work. Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we are once again talking about Egypt, a champion country of human rights violations where electroshock is used on children's genitals, to set a macabre example. We have made resolutions, there have been international calls, reports from many non-governmental organisations, but no response, indeed arrogant responses from those who know that they can count on general impunity. We have our own boy, an Italian boy but also a European boy, Giulio Regeni, who was brutally murdered and tortured three years ago and we still have neither truth nor justice for this boy. So I ask myself: with this resolution we continue to do our duty as the European Parliament, but does the Commission want to try to make some progress? What kind of blackmail do we suffer from Egypt in order to continue to endure this kind of human rights violations?

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo
text: Author. – Mr President, in 2013 the Egyptian army murdered hundreds of people protesting in Rabaa Square. While none of those responsible have been tried, however, 75 of these protesters have been sentenced to death. This is another example of impunity and general repression in Egypt.  A country where 65,000 political prisoners have been imprisoned in the past five years and more than 1,500 people have been victims of enforced disappearances. A country where human rights defenders are being persecuted: women like Amal Fathy, imprisoned for denouncing that the Government does not protect women who, like her, have been victims of sexual violence. A country that is forebehaving asylum seekers from Sudan, Eritrea, Yemen or Syria. A country which, according to the European Union, is a follow-up example in migration and, of course, a magnificent trading partner.  We call on the European Union to react, to suspend the Association Agreement and all cooperation programmes agreed with the Egyptian authorities until basic democratic rights are respected. We call on Member States, such as Spain, to stop selling weapons and surveillance equipment to Egypt because they are being used to crack down on civil society.  Once again, we repeat in this House: economic and commercial interests cannot be above human rights.

name: Soraya Post
text: author. – Mr President, the Egyptian women’s rights activist Amal Fathy has been sentenced to two years in prison for something thousands of women have done during the #MeToo movement. She posted a video on her Facebook page, where she shared her experience of sexual harassment and she criticised the Egyptian Government for not acting to protect women. Amal is not the only person in Egypt who has been jailed for the peaceful exercise of freedom of expression. The Egyptian Government must release immediately all human rights defenders, peaceful activists, lawyers, bloggers and journalists; must drop all the baseless criminal investigations of NGOs; and must stop applying the death penalty against individuals, including two children under the age of 18. It’s shameful.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: author. – Mr President, many in the European Union see Egypt as an important partner in countering terrorism, managing migration and ensuring stability in an already explosive Middle East. And yes, Egypt is an important country and that is why it is so crucial not to repeat the mistakes of the past, where the severe oppression of peoples’ rights led to anything but stability. I think there is repetition going on – and it’s a ticking time bomb – as enforced disappearances, torture, executions and a crackdown on civil society organisations, journalists and other human rights defenders continue. This crisis of human rights and the enforced disappearances really hit home to many in Europe with the Giulio Regeni case, but in fact they impact on the entire Egyptian population. We wanted to see for ourselves what the human rights situation in Egypt was like, but unfortunately, we were unable to travel to Egypt next week. I think that this is very problematic and it needs to be addressed, because we need to stay in contact and be able to convey in person our serious concerns about the lack of respect for human rights in Egypt.

name: Barbara Matera
text: Author. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have been very and personally interested in this motion for a resolution for two reasons: firstly because Egypt is a strategic economic and political partner for the European Union and, secondly, because a dispute between Egypt and Italy over the case of Giulio Regeni, a boy brutally tortured and killed in February 2016, is still active and alive. Egypt is going through a delicate period: it is getting up and is on a path of institutional reform. We, as the European Union, want to be friends for Egypt and its people, privileged partners to accompany it through the long process of institutional reform. It is important that fundamental democratic rights, such as freedom of expression, online and offline, as well as freedom of association, political pluralism and the rule of law in Egypt are strengthened. These are cornerstones of a democratic and pluralist nation, they are the fundamental characteristics to mediate between oppositions and avoid wars and conflicts. History teaches us that democracy is not perfect, but it ensures peace and prosperity. We ask the Egyptian people and their government for clarity and truth for Giulio Regeni, a European boy who loved to study, worked so hard, was indeed a special person. We do this not out of politics, but we really do it to give back to his family and to the Truth of Europe the truth of a boy and his story.

name: Pavel Svoboda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, unfortunately, there are widespread human rights violations in Egypt. Moreover, their detention was often not preceded by legal proceedings that met the essential requirements of a fair trial. We ask today that all these illegally detained people be released. Egypt has not improved the protection of its Christians, even though they make up 10% of the population, but they are still being confronted with violence by Islamic fundamentalists. And so Egypt is on a sad map of those states where it is difficult to exercise freedom of religion. In 2018, Islamists attacked a bus of Christian pilgrims, killing seven of them. Of course, we want the best possible relations, but it is important to apply the more for more principle in all areas of relations with Egypt. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I wanted to ask whether you are to blame for the actions of Islamic terrorists murdering Christians, a government that is fighting them and which is trying to protect society from both Muslims and Christians from this kind of terrorist anti-human activity. Well, let's not confuse cause and effect.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. - Thank you for the question, just because I know about it. I therefore point out that the Egyptian Government must do more to protect this group from Islamist fanatics.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Standing High Commission on Human Rights has been set up in Egypt on behalf of the Group of the Party of European People's Party (European Democrats) and European Democrats. From the premises, it seems that this new body is more about protecting the image of the country than about human rights. Egypt is certainly an important partner for the European Union, but there are principles and values that must take precedence over a realpolitik driven solely by balances of power and commercial interests. These are civil, democratic and human rights that every country must guarantee in order to have relations with the European Union, but that is not what we have in Egypt, unfortunately.
