There are activists, journalists and lawyers imprisoned and convicted for their ideas, there are mass trials that result in death sentences that are based neither on evidence nor on concrete investigations. There are also two parents, giulio regeni's parents, looking for a truth explaining why Giulio was tortured and killed and why the Egyptian authorities are covering up the responsibilities. The proposed resolution is intended to place the agenda and the urgency of a human rights agenda in Egypt strongly, and this agenda – I ask you, Commissioner – must be imposed by the European Union with strength and determination.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen
text: for the ECR Group. Mr President! Again, we are debating the situation in Egypt in this Chamber and, although there are worrying tendencies, I think we should remember that our history, both here in the European Parliament and by the Commission in relation to Egypt, is rather tarnished. After all, we actively supported the so-called Arab Spring, and the consequences it had for Egypt were completely insurmountable, both for the country itself and for Europe. A stable Egypt, which is prospering economically, is in europe's strong interest, and the worst thing that could happen to European stability in our immediate areas is precisely a destabilised Egypt. That is why I think this resolution is highly problematic. I think it is very one-sided. I think there are many other countries that could rightly have been criticised for the same things and even worse violations, and I honestly think that the Egyptians should have been given the opportunity to show progress rather than constantly be on their side by this Parliament.

name: Marisa Matias
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, Egypt is certainly an important partner of the European Union and is a neighbouring country with which we have many centuries of common history.  I have been working with the Egyptian authorities since 2009 and that is why all we have to say we must say quite frankly and eye to eye. There are trade agreements between the European Union and Egypt. We recognize the sovereignty of the Egyptian people, but we cannot continue to turn a blind eye to the systematic violation of human rights in the name of commercial interests.  What we see in Egypt is the closure of the political space, the severe limitations on freedom of expression, of opinion, of association.  There can be no impunity in relation to human rights, either in Egypt or in the European Union or anywhere in the world. For the sake of good relations, we cannot continue to close our eyes or cover our ears to all the appeals and denunciations that come to us from citizens and civil society organisations and which, I believe, are just the tip of the iceberg. Respecting human rights by the Egyptian authorities is a favour that is done, first of all, to the Egyptian people themselves.

name: Ana Miranda
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, the European Union continues to negotiate with Egypt, a country that persecutes and kills human rights defenders. We have seen it there and so we transfer it to the high representative in the framework of the political dialogue. This Resolution is an urgent call on European states to stop the sale of security equipment technology to Egypt, ordering the suspension of all military support. But this has not happened, because we see how Member States continue to sell rifles, tanks and torture equipment that hurt and kill the Egyptian population; human rights defenders, too. Like the Spanish state, for example, it closed a arms sales business for more than one hundred million euros between 2016 and 2017. How many human rights defenders and civilians will continue to be killed, in this case also by the bombs of the Spanish state? What is the Commission doing to stop this blood trade that goes against Egyptians and, above all, that is violating all international and human rights legislation?

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, three years have passed since the brutal murder of Giulio Regeni, and I can only imagine how his family can feel, every day and, even more so, during these holidays, in continuing to have no answer and no justice. Apart from empty reassurances, pats on the back and promises of good intentions, the Egyptian authorities are still not cooperating: the fog of impunity and thicker than ever. That is why the Italian Chamber of Deputies has suspended relations with the Egyptian Parliament, in order to give a shock, a signal, and to remember that if the world is forgetting, or perhaps has already forgotten, we are not, we will not forget and we will not forget. The Union has the ambition to be a global geopolitical player, capable of influencing global dynamics. In fact, he cannot even get answers when a European citizen – because Giulio was a European citizen, as well as being an Italian citizen – is barbarically tortured and killed. I say this loud and clear: if the Eu ropean Union really were to put the same commitment in the search for the truth as it does in controlling the decimal points of the budgets, we would probably already have the answers. I support this resolution, but I say even more that realpolitik must not prevail. Let us follow the example of the Chamber of Deputies: let us break down relations until we make a mockery of ourselves, until there is truth and justice for Giulio Regeni.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, no less than seven rapporteurs have just attacked Egypt, yet Marshal Al-Sissi is a bulwark against Islamism. He came to power in 2013 by overthrowing Islamist President Mohamed Morsi, who was on the verge of leading Egypt into chaos. In 2014, the Egyptian people legitimized their action by electing him to the presidency of the Republic. Since then, he has been a tireless fighter fighting Islamist terrorism, both ideologically and militarily. Thus he courageously asserts that Islam must be renovated to combat the most obscurantist tendencies of this religion. That is why the European Union should support Marshal Al-Sissi instead of blaming him for any violation of human rights, because if his regime were to collapse, it would be a country of 92 million people, Egypt, which would risk falling into Islamism and lending the hand to terrorism. The tragedy we have just experienced in Strasbourg should encourage the European Parliament to be more realistic. Our mission is to protect Europeans and not to give moral lessons to our partners.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: – I am concerned about further systematic reports of human rights violations and violations of the rule of law in Egypt. I am very concerned about information about interfering with and controlling freedom of expression and the media, as well as violations of the foundations of the democratic rule of law, such as the arrests of political opponents or human rights defenders. I would like to stress with full force that Egypt is a strategic partner for the European Union in the region, playing a particularly important role in the peace talks and stability in the Mediterranean. That is also why we cannot categorically agree to human rights violations, the country's departure from the democratic system and the direction of authoritarian governments, which in turn are the cradle of extremism.

name: Wajid Khan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, for the second time this year we are raising the alarming situation of human rights in Egypt. The Egyptian authorities must stop the crackdown on human rights defenders, who are disappearing at an alarming rate. Egypt must immediately release Amal Fathy, Ismail al-Iskandarani, Hisham Gaafar and all those who have been detained for peacefully expressing their opinion. I urge the Member States to be united and to speak with one voice during the upcoming EU—Egypt Association Council, to continue applying pressure on President al-Sisi. We must reconsider our level of engagement and cooperation with Egypt if it continues to disregard international law. Fundamental democratic rights, such as freedom of expression, political pluralism and the rule of law, must be guaranteed.  Let me be clear. If Egypt wants to be more than a neighbour, and to become an important partner country to the EU, there is only one way: to make concrete progress on its human rights record.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The day before yesterday, we saw another tragic event on the streets of Strasbourg that made up this long war of Islamist terrorism against the peoples of Europe, but a similar war is taking place in Egypt. Egypt's authorities must confront the Islamic State caliphate in Sinai, the underground linked to the ousted Muslim Brotherhood, attacks on the church and this struggle, the Egyptian authorities are conducting in the interests of international peace and social peace. Of course, every human power, especially in times of dramatic social conflicts, can make mistakes, I have full understanding for my Italian colleagues who demand clarification on their citizens, but in this dramatic situation where the West has so few allies, our allies are, above all, guilty of being recognised for fighting for social and international peace and solidarity. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you very much, dear colleague. Indeed, probably we should have to look in a more balanced way at the situation. On one side, the fact that the Egyptian authorities don’t respect human rights, civil rights and non—governmental organisations; on the other side, they cooperate with the European Union on fighting terrorism, radicalisation, and so on and so forth. But don’t you think – because we have here the Commissioner for Development – that European Union should have to use a very important leverage with all these countries, because we give them lots of money for development projects? This should have to be used when these countries – including Tanzania, which we are going to speak about later – are doing all these things that are against European Union values.

name: President. –
text: By the way, Mr Frunzulică, there is no space for a statement. It’s space for a question.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. "Of course I thank my mate for this question. You are absolutely right that, in our bilateral relations, the diplomacy of the European Union should use this to draw attention to situations that require the intervention of the authorities, for example when it comes to controlling the forces of order. This is clear, but at the same time it is very worrying that if, in the statements not diplomatic, but public, political, as in this House, we are not talking about the real threats to human rights in Egypt, about the activities of the Islamic State caliphate in Sinai, about the burning churches, about the underground of the Muslim Brotherhood, about what Egypt has led, but also the world, professor Mursi's rule, the governments ousted by Marshal As-Sisi.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Mr President, the Islamist attack in France in Strasbourg on Tuesday should teach us that in politics we must choose between friends and enemies. It is the identification of the enemy that transforms a politician into a statesman, like Winston Churchill. Marshal Al-Sissi in Egypt understands the danger of Islamism and the Muslim Brotherhood. His speech to Al-Azhar University in Cairo in 2015 was a statement to the highest authority in Sunni Islam that Islamist extremism also has its roots in an interpretation of Islam itself. President Al-Sissi, a Muslim, is currently seeking to have the Muslim Brotherhood listed as a terrorist organization. The hostile resolutions tabled against Egypt by the liberal, socialist and communist groups in this chamber do not explain anywhere the context of its difficult action. Do you believe, ladies and gentlemen, that radical Islam is more respectful of human rights?  Faced with the camp that chose to wage war on us, you have chosen, in Churchill's words, dishonour and you will have war, with civil war, in our country too, because Islamism is our home.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, is tír álainn í an Éigipt ag ár dteorainn ag an deisceart. Tá gaol maith againn léi agus is maith sin. Tá a lán dul chun cinn á dhéanamh inti. Ach, ag an am céanna, mar a dúirt mo chomhghleacaithe, ní hé sin le rá gur cheart dúinn súil dhall a thabhairt ar na drochrudaí dorcha atá ag tarlú ansin, go háirithe maidir le cearta daonna a shéanadh ar dhaoine agus a lán daoine i bpríosún gan chúis, gan triail. Dá bhrí sin, is ceart agus is cóir go bpléifimis na rudaí seo sa Pharlaimint.  Agus is féidir toradh dearfach a bheith ar an tuarascáil seo, mar, cúpla bliain ó shin, bhí mé féin agus mo chomh-Fheisirí ó Éirinn ag obair ar thuarascáil maidir le hIbrahim Halawa - fear óg a bhí i bpríosún gan chúis, gan triail arís - agus tar éis na tuarascála, ligeadh saor é. Tá sé ar ais anois in Éirinn. Dá bhrí sin, is féidir linn brú a chur ar údaráis san Éigipt maidir leis na cúiseanna seo, agus le cúnamh Dé, beidh toradh dearfach air, cosúil le hIbrahim Halawa.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the human rights situation in Egypt is deteriorating. As noted in the draft resolution, the Egyptian Government is heavily reliant on death penalties and harsh enforcement measures. People undergo torture, and human rights are not protected. I’m particularly concerned by the abuses of children that have been reported. According to Human Rights Watch, of the thousands of cases heard in military courts since 2014, over 150 involved children facing trial. According to a UN report in 2015, children with disabilities often go without access to education. This is not a country where young people can flourish. Europe is Egypt’s first trading partner. The EU—Egypt Partnership Priorities 2017—2020 were adopted last year and the EU is in a good position to influence what the Egyptian state does, and to take the action that’s required.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for almost 35 months we have had to ask for and continue to demand truth and justice for Giulio Regeni. It is a good thing that Today, with this resolution, Parliament is once again strongly calling for the full cooperation of the Egyptian authorities with the Italian authorities in their investigations and interrogations and also for the safety of Italian and Egyptian lawyers who are investigating to find the truth. We must also put an end to the violence, torture and enforced disappearances in Egypt. It is good that the resolution calls for the release of Amal Fathy, immediately and unconditionally, and also for the various human rights defenders who are unlawfully detained. Another thing I would like to add is that we cannot regard – no European country should consider – Egypt as a safe country, there are no conditions. Furthermore, stopping selling arms to the Al Sisi regime would be a good start, and I say this to some governments that are continuing to do so. If you put before you the commercial interests and the obsession with blocking migrants, you are betraying the fundamental rights that we have put at the base of this Union. So, really, we seek consistency and seek truth and justice for what happened to Giulio Regeni.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the European Union has a clear interest in Egypt’s long-term stability and security. At the same time, it is our firm conviction that this can be achieved only if human rights are fully implemented and upheld, as guaranteed by the 2014 Egyptian constitution and in accordance with Egypt’s international commitments. Consequently, the European Union continually encourages Egypt to improve the situation with regard to civil and political rights, including freedom of expression both online and offline, and to respect the rights of human rights defenders, in accordance with international human rights law and with the relevant provisions in the Egyptian constitution. The European Parliament, the European External Action Service and civil society regularly interact and cooperate on issues related to the situation of human rights defenders in Egypt. The charges most commonly filed against human rights defenders are, among others, those of acceptance of illegal foreign funding, spread of false news and misuse of social media. In our dialogue with Egypt we regularly raise the increasing number of arrests of human rights defenders and activists, which is of great concern. This was also raised publicly in a statement issued by the High Representative’s spokesperson in May 2018. The European Union is deeply concerned, too, about reports of torture, forced disappearances and the poor detention conditions to which human rights defenders and other detainees are subjected. There is a clear need for accountability for all forms of pressure, harassment and violence against human rights defenders.  Furthermore, the EU welcomes the announcement that the NGO law will be reviewed. We hope that this revision will address concerns about provisions such as those on the registration process, the activities NGOs are allowed to perform and procedures in connection with the receipt of domestic and foreign funding. To this end, we urge Egypt to engage in a meaningful, inclusive and extensive dialogue with civil society in the process of revising the law. Next week’s EU-Egypt Association Council, on 20 December, will provide yet another forum in which to discuss the situation for the human rights defenders in Egypt.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place at the end of the debates.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Tanzania (2018/2969(RSP)).

name: Judith Sargentini
text: Author. Mr President, in 2015 I was chief observer for the European observation mission to the presidential elections in Tanzania, the elections that brought President Magufuli to power. President Kikwete had his legal term over and the governing party came up with a new candidate. That's good news, because things can be different. There are plenty of examples in Africa where a president wants to stay put too long.  The elections in that country actually went pretty well. I am not talking about Zanzibar, because it got completely out of hand there, but on the mainland the elections went quite well. President Magufuli started very promisingly with anti-corruption campaigns and Tanzania was also known as a beacon of calm in the region – the East Africa region, with Burundi, Uganda, Kenya, often has very troubled elections.  But now, three years after the 2015 election, we have to conclude that it's all wrong. The opposition is intimidated, threatened and even murdered. In Dar es Salaam, Paul Makonda, the government's highest representative, launched a witch hunt against LGBT people. People are even lynched because they're not heterosexual. President Magufuli forbids schoolgirls who become pregnant from going to school any longer. Anti-corruption programs seem to have been put on ice.  From a stable country it has become a country where there is currently a lawless situation. So much so that the World Bank has decided to stop initiatives and the European External Action Service is trying to do the same. The european delegation's chief mission has been brought back to Europe and relations with Tanzania are being reconsidered. I think that is very sensible of Vice-President Mogherini and I would also like to see this resolution as a support for the policy and a support for the democratic opposition in Tanzania. You've been seen. You're not alone.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: Author. Mr President, since John Magufuli came to power in 2015, the situation in Tanzania has deteriorated, and this has been particularly true since the beginning of the year. Journalists, bloggers, political opponents, rights defenders can be arrested at any time or even murdered.  On 22 February, Mr Godfrey Luena, a member of parliament from the main opposition party, was killed with a machete outside his home. Six television channels and two radio stations were suspended. In March, a new communications law subjected all online radio or television stations to a licence and a fee of 900 euros, an exorbitant sum for the country.  Any content that causes embarrassment or leads to public disorder can now be removed through a new cybercrime law. Homosexuality is punishable by up to 30 years in prison or even life in prison, and the regional commissioner of Dar es Salam has threatened to round up all those suspected of homosexuality for tests and conversion therapies. Girls experience sexual violence and forced marriage and are excluded from school if they are pregnant.  This does not prevent tourism from developing, especially in the beautiful Serengeti region. This could be a boon if land controls for speculative purposes do not increase tensions in the region to the detriment, in particular, of the Maasai populations. It seems that Tingatinga, the "bulldozer", the president's nickname, now destroys much more than he builds.

name: Soraya Post
text: author. – Mr President, sadly enough, we have to remind the authorities and the Government of Tanzania that LGBTI rights and women’s rights are human rights. The Tanzanian Government has an obligation to protect the rights and dignity of all its citizens. I demand that Tanzania cancel its laws criminalising homosexuality and stop the arrest and violence against LGBTI people, and health and human rights activists. I demand that the Tanzanian Government immediately cancel the law banning pregnant girls from attending school, and also girls who have given birth have to be able to return to school. The right to education is a human right and needs to be respected all over the world.

name: Seán Kelly
text: author. – Mr President, I reiterate the call to Member States to encourage third countries, such as Tanzania, to protect LGBTI human rights defenders and to decriminalise homosexuality, as is happening in many countries around the world. The deteriorating state of human rights in Tanzania is blocking the country’s development, prosperity, peace and security, and indeed good relations with other countries, including the European Union. I welcome the call to review restrictions placed on the press and to respect the right to life and dignity of all citizens. The exclusion of pregnant girls and adolescent mothers from schools is a matter of extreme concern and a very backward approach. These young women have a right to access quality education and it is crucial that Tanzania ends this ban immediately. I support Vice-President / High Representative Mogherini in her work in trying to bring sense to this chaotic situation.

name: Elena Valenciano
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, this more than a debate is a complaint about the serious deterioration of human rights that is happening in Tanzania. A deterioration that is visible to all those of us who have a certain sensitivity for the protection of fundamental human rights.  In the face of this accelerated deterioration, in the face of this near-hunting persecution against the LGBTI collective, it is up to us to ask the Member States and the Commission to urgently review our relations with Tanzania; that we demand from Tanzania a change in its repressive legislation, its absolutely degrading legislation, also in its action, against the most vulnerable groups: gay, lesbian, transgender, women too, girls. And we are therefore here to demand that the Council address relations with Tanzania from this perspective. Respect for human rights; respect for minorities; respect for all sexual options; and, if not, urgent review of our relations with that country.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, President John Magufuli's repressive policy is making great strides towards Nazism, now that the hunt for gays is officially open. The goal of his friend Paul Makonda, governor of Dar es Salaam, is to cleanse society of western evil that offends the moral values of Tanzanians: sex and above all fearsome homosexuality. The government's incendiary and sexophobic rhetoric has therefore moved on to action, even assisted by a task force to identify and arrest members of the LGBTI community. What is more, President Magufuli has also banned mothers from entering school, a serious and definitive removal from culture, training and probably even the world of work for these poor girls, for what obscure reason, we do not know. What worries me is not so much the deliri of a bigoted president and a governor taking orders from God, but the incitement to hatred and diverted rhetoric that are poisoning the population. In the light of this absurd scenario, I believe it is necessary to review and possibly suspend our relations with Tanzania, at least until it ends this unworthy persecution.

name: David Martin (S&D).
text: – Mr President, for me, this is a desperately sad situation, because for many decades Tanzania seemed slowly to be going in the right direction and many of us indeed welcomed President Magufuli’s election in 2015, when he promised to tackle corruption, improve governance and reform the economy. Sadly, his crackdown on corruption has been replaced by a crackdown on anyone critical of his rule. Journalists are detained and harassed, opposition politicians are threatened, attacked, and, as we’ve heard in this Chamber today, in one case even murdered. International organisations are not immune from this either. Our own ambassador has had to be forcefully recalled from the country.  Although the government has distanced itself from some of the more extreme comments that have been made about the LGBTI community, it is clear they are not doing anything like enough to protect that community and more must be done. I’m afraid, after years of advocating closer relationship between the EU and Tanzania, I have to agree with those who say we now have to rethink our relationship with that country.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I rise to add my voice to the concerns of this House about the deteriorating human rights situation in Tanzania. Not only has the Government of President Magufuli been cracking down on the media – as we’ve heard – but, more alarmingly, it is also violating the rights of LGBTI people and preventing young girls who are pregnant from attending school. On top of this, we’ve had the Regional Commissioner Makonda threatening to arrest and chase all gay men out of Dar es Salaam. This is outrageous.  All of these violate our strictest values. Therefore, I welcome that our relationship with Tanzania is under review by the Commission and that we have recalled our Ambassador. My questions to the Commissioner are: are we considering withholding aid, like Denmark has done, and, following the briefings from our Ambassador there, what are the next steps? What are we going to do to address these concerns? Secondly, on a much broader issue, how can we ensure that the EU’s policy on human rights moves away from a reactive towards a more pre—emptive approach. Finally, given the trend of increasing online media censorship and a lack of international standards on this, what steps have we taken to actively shape international norms?

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I want to join my colleagues in clearly describing the situation in Tanzania. President Magufoli's government is very disappointing for us, we have been waiting for him to make real reforms to the country, to fight corruption, and instead we are seeing a hunt for members of sexual minorities, pregnant girls, opposition leaders and so on. This means that the situation is going in a very bad direction, and I have a question for the Commissioner: How exactly will the Commission respond to this? I think it is necessary that the way the situation in Tanzania develops should have an impact on the relations between the European Union and Tanzania, and that we end not only with proclamations, with political and moral condemnation of the situation in Tanzania, but that we translate our political position into action. This means that this should have an impact on the Economic Assistance to Tanzania by the European Union and, say, on the tightening of diplomatic and public pressure on the country.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am appalled by the situation in Tanzania, where civil society organisations and human rights defenders are being attacked on a daily basis. Last month, the authorities asked the public to report the name of any person suspected of being gay, pledging that a special team would ‘get their hands on them’. I am also very worried about the safety of hundreds of people who are facing serious threats because of their sexual orientation or gender identity or expression, real or perceived. Just yesterday, another LGBT community centre was attacked, and government incitement clearly plays a role in provoking violence, hatred and xenophobia.  Respecting and promoting all human rights are international obligations. Tanzania has a duty to respect these obligations and must not incite or perpetrate violence against any minorities. I support the EU’s decision to recall its ambassador in Dar es Salaam to Brussels for consultations on this urgent situation and to review its relationship with Tanzania. At last week’s ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly in Benin, I was able to ask both the ACP and EU Councils what they are doing to stop these attacks. I have to tell you, the ACP response was sorely lacking.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the situation in Tanzania is out of control. We note that President Magufuli is now persecuting the opposition, the civil society groups, the parties with which he does not agree. He's shut down radio stations and newspapers. From then on, what it does is also pursue a policy which essentially encourages sexual violence. We have excluded pregnant women and girls from schools, which is unacceptable. We also note that land is now being snatched in the Masai land area. Land that is arable is taken for profit. It is obvious that the European Union should take very specific measures against the Tanzanian Government.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, homosexuality is not a human right in Dar es Salaam. It was with these shameful words that on 31 October Paul Makonda, the governor of the region, began a veritable witch-hunt against homosexuals, stigmatised as guilty of a carnal sin against the order of nature. We are faced with yet another manifestation of a seriously widespread homophobia that has been tolerated for too long in Tanzania, a country where there are still laws today that punish the crime of homosexuality with thirty years in prison. But the LGBTI community is not alone in being targeted. From the Magufuli elections in 2015, there has been a terrible general deterioration in human rights, to the imposition of an absurd ban on mother girls returning to school after childbirth. These young people, many of whom are victims of violence, thus become the new enemies of a state that forces them to choose between their education and their child. I call on the Tanzanian authorities to lift this senseless ban immediately, as well as other laws against the LGBTI community. On the other hand, I call on the European Union, as announced by the High Representative, to finally and as soon as possible review its policies towards Tanzania. Let us enforce these human rights clauses in Cotonou, in the agreements we have signed, otherwise they are just waste paper.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am consistently opposed to Parliament writing such a resolution. Parliament is a legislative body for Europeans and should pass laws, solve their problems, and not review the situation around the world. We are writing such resolutions, meanwhile, three for each session. That's about thirty-six a year, or one hundred and eighty during his tenure. This means, statistically, that virtually every country in the world has received at least one addressed resolution from us in one term of office. What is the effect of this?  No. It serves no purpose. These are just columns that Parliament is releasing all over the world. No one outside Parliament is likely to read this. So it's a waste of time that only amazes voters. What are we doing here? The situation in Tanzania? The situation in Burundi? People in Europe often don't know where the countries we are in lie. Our knowledge of the subject is also poor. We know the situation only from press reports and those that we consider ourselves reliable. Few of us were there. A majority of Members do not know what they are voting on. Over-attention is paid to LGBT people and women when discussing these issues, which also amazes Europeans. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – How can the honourable deputy say we are wasting our time and that people don’t know what the European Union is when, as I pointed out in the debate on Egypt, we had a resolution here on Ibrahim Halawa and subsequent to that resolution, with pressure from the Commission and the Irish Government, the Egyptians agreed to release him?

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. –I am sorry, but this is a very naïve vision of politics. International policy is not cultivated by the writing of resolutions. This is a paper policy that gives nothing. Will anyone read it? Do you think that in Tanzania, the people who decide on its policies do so because they do not know that the European Union opposes it? Well, they certainly know already. And as the Lord will write to them now, nothing will change because of it. This is simply a useless way of doing politics.  If we want to put pressure on, of course, there are different means of this squeeze, but most often the less you talk about it, the better, because you have to act by surprise and you have to be able to put pressure in such a way that it is effective and severe for the side you want to press. So I think this kind of policy is just useless. What are the effects besides that? Let's look at the effects so far, they are none.  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio (PPE)
text: "blue card" question. – Mr Sosnierz, I wanted to ask you: do you have daughters? Do you have sisters? Do you have a mother? You say what matters to women there. I care and most of us here care. And what you say about not changing anything is not true. I guarantee you that I have many Venezuelan friends, exiled friends, people who are threatened, people who are in jail and say, "Please don't shut up, don't shut up." Because any cause has to be defended with a speaker and we here are the speaker of people who don't have a voice. We are lending them our voice, because the citizens have chosen us to speak on their behalf, in the name of human rights.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by First of all, these are the ad personam arguments that you are using now, which is to hook someone up, whether they have children or not – yes I have children, but I will not talk about such things here, because these are private matters, so please do not ask me about it. There are many problems in the world, and it can be said every time that the public ity of something can contribute to solving it, but it usually does not contribute, especially if the European Parliament, in the case of our resolutions, has seen such inflation of their importance. If you use it as a unique tool for some unique problem, then it can make a difference.  But if we spend it three per session, no one can keep up with it anymore, nobody reads it, nobody cares.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I, listening to my colleague Sośnierz, would never say that I will miss Mr Korwin-Mikke. That's a very sad finding for me.  But let us focus on Tanzania, because the problems of people who are actually suffering are important to us in this debate. I would like to support my colleagues who have described the situation in Tanzania. It is completely unacceptable how the government that we looked up to with some hope, which was supposed to be a government, is turning right in front of our eyes into a regime that oppresses human rights, attacks people, suppresses the opposition, journalists, the LGBT community, confiscates property there. These are indeed the facts that we must mention here. It is not in vain, Mr Sośnierz, it is quite clearly important to send this message. We have the means to intervene. Mr. Kelly told you. I think it is now the Commission's role to take action against the Government in Tanzania and to make it clear that this cannot have our support and then our support cannot go there.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would also like to apologise to the Commissioner for not being here from the beginning of the debate, but there are now six other events in the House at the same time. At the same time we have votes in the Committee on Budgets, we have votes in the Committee on Budgetary Control, we have a trade preparatory meeting, we have the EEA group here, we have a STOA meeting and it is also the plenary. name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, for many decades the European Union and its Member States have enjoyed close and fruitful relations with the United Republic of Tanzania and have been its main development partner and one of its top trade and investment partners. This partnership has been rooted in shared fundamental values such as democracy, human rights and the rule of law and in a common involvement in peace promotion, effective multilateralism and regional integration.  However, over the past years, we have noticed the shrinking of public space in Tanzania through the threats, harassment, persecution and tightening of restrictions on the activities of civil society organisations – the LGBTI community, the media and many political parties. Respect for human rights and the rule of law has been repeatedly undermined.  The European Union expressed its concerns publicly in September through a statement during the 39th session of the United Nations Human Rights Council in Geneva and reiterated them in a declaration of the High Representative, Federica Mogherini, on behalf of the European Union, published on 15 November.  This situation, combined with other elements, has led to growing pressure from the Tanzanian authorities for the forced departure of the EU ambassador in Tanzania and ultimately led to the EU’s decision to recall him to headquarters for consultations. The EU deeply regrets this unprecedented attitude, which is not in line with our long-established dialogue with Tanzania.  At this stage, together with Member States, the European Union has furthermore decided to conduct a comprehensive review of our policies and the relations towards Tanzania. The review will also include issues related to human rights and the rule of law, as well as our development cooperation. As underlined in the statement of 15 November, it is important to send a strong message to Tanzania while maintaining engagement with actors from all spheres of political, economic, social and cultural life, including civil society. The structured political dialogue with the Tanzanian government will resume once the review of the relationship has been completed, with a view to resetting our bonds on a more trustful and forward-looking basis.  Let me set this in the broader context of EU relations with Africa. In Abidjan in November 2017, we agreed to an agenda based on shared interests and shared values. The European Union will always look at our relations with each African partner in a comprehensive way, including our common long-term interests.  Therefore, European Union remains committed to a sound relationship with a stable, democratic and inclusive Tanzania, fully involved in the regional integration process.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – No violence or inhuman treatment can be justified in any country in the world. I believe that Tanzania must cooperate with the rest of the world, gaining experience in the context of peace. It is necessary to create conditions conducive to life, education, work and full development for citizens. The stabilisation process should include the establishment of a sustainable legal framework and effective enforcement. Action is needed to show people and demonstrate that order and stability can prevail in the country. An independent judicial system should be established, children and women should be protected, including the prevention of violence, a favourable medium for the dissemination of knowledge and information, and access to the necessary health services and tools. The country should not be politically isolated from other countries. Cooperation in various policy areas needs to be strengthened and substantial international agreements establishing, for example, the protection of human rights must be signed. Measures and methods to combat crime, effective and impartial police activities are also necessary. Tanzania must take immediate political action to restore people's trust in public power.

name: Philippe Lamberts (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we all received a package a few weeks ago from an American firm called, if I recall, Facebook. In addition to this package of paper and plastic being a form of waste of energy and resources, I note that the American firm is actually sending us advertising materials to commit us to use its services more and more in the upcoming election campaign, but the same American company continues to evade its own commitments that it made during Mr. Zuckerberg's visit to Parliament. I insist that the Presidency of Parliament remind Facebook of its commitments and obligations.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr Lamberts. I think everyone draws their own conclusions from this. You can also send such packages back.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I will be very brief and extremely short.  Not only must we support what Mr Lamberts has just said, but I would like to point out that, despite all the customs, in an inter-institutional trilogue where no lobby has anything to do, three weeks ago, after the plenary vote on the copyright text, only three weeks ago, YouTube, Google and a few others were in this room of the European Parliament. , in the restaurant of the European Parliament, at the request of the rapporteur for that matter, which is not glorious, neither for his group nor for himself, to try to make us change our positions. Mr President, do you want to make the minutes that we ask that, from the vote of a plenary, lobbies be totally, near or far, banned in the inter-institutional phases?

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the vote. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes.)

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, we have carefully assessed the draft negotiation position of the Parliament and listened to the statement of the ECON chair before, however we are convinced that the draft negotiation position of the Parliament is not good enough. It is not enough to get the risks in the balance sheets of European banks under control, and it is not enough to prevent indebted consumers and small enterprises from being abused by unregulated credit purchases. The stock of non-performing loans is bigger today than it was before the last financial crisis. Nevertheless, the new rules for the provisioning of bad loans will only apply to newly issued loans, and only for this partial solution the European Parliament’s position is weaker than of the Council and weaker than of the European Commission. But tough minimum requirements for credit provisioning for non-performing loans are necessary so that taxpayers do not have to rescue struggling banks again in the next economic downturn.  Lastly, those who now demand weaker rules on these loans are risking that the banking union cannot be completed. Even worse, there are no binding rules so far for the credit purchases, and this means that BlackRock, Blackstone and many other credit purchases can continue driving people who are indebted from their homes, and this is why we think this negotiation position is not good enough and we ask colleagues to send the committee back to the drawing desk in order to have strong rules on consumer protection and strong rules on our banks.  (Applause)

name: Roberto Gualtieri
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, actually what colleague Giegold is saying is not true. This is a balanced compromise – basically identical to the position unanimously voted by the Council, being welcomed by the Commission – and this ensures actually a very prudent calendar provisioning for NPLs, while avoiding the risk that too rigid provisions and the one that you are asking for would negatively affect consumer SMEs. Honestly, I find your arguments totally contradictory. You make propaganda about the consumers, but what you would like to do, is exactly what would bring people with the mortgages, SMEs, into the hands of hedge funds – American hedge funds. So, it’s totally contradictory, what you are saying.  (Applause) And second, the reason the reason why the Greens are making this objection is basically political, because we reached a balanced compromise with the EPP and you didn’t like that and I’m proud to do that because I have many different views with the EPP, but I’m proud that in this House we are able also to find common ground and to find together good legislation. This makes Europe stronger, not weaker, and that’s why I think we have to endorse this compromise. (Applause)

name: Massimiliano Salini
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would simply like to request referral back to the ITRE Committee on Interinstitutional Negotiations, pursuant to Rule 59.

name: Angelika Mlinar
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank my colleagues for this broad support. And in accordance with Rule 59, as rapporteur, I would like to propose that the matter be referred back to the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy for interinstitutional negotiations.

The same applies in the election campaign: you only earn the respect that you give to others. (Applause) That concludes the vote.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the negotiations of the budget for 2019 has been particularly challenging this year, and therefore I thank Mr Viotti for his hard work. I also contributed to the EP draft budget, paying special attention to the budget of EU agencies in the area of freedom, security and justice. Unfortunately, when the mandate of an agency is expanded, it does not necessarily result in the increase of its budget. Do we really expect our agencies and justice and home affairs to deliver more results with fewer resources? It seems that the Council really believes so, which I – as an MEP – deem unacceptable.  However, I would like to make a positive comment on the increase of EUR 943 million obtained in the negotiations. They correspond to Parliament’s main political priorities – namely, in support of researchers, young people, SMEs, tackling the root causes of migration, climate change and increasing the security of EU citizens. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, first of all, may I thank you for the brisk and efficient way in which, as usual, you’ve conducted the vote, and may I take this opportunity to wish you and all of the staff and interpreters a very happy Christmas. One of the outcomes of the recent protests in France is that the French budget is now plainly going to spiral beyond the limits allowed in European treaties. We’re always told that this is a law—based organisation that has to follow its rules. I just want to leave Members as they head back to their constituencies with one question: when a eurosceptic government in Italy looked as though it might breach the deficit rules, it was universally condemned and an alternative budget was cooked up in Brussels. Will that same standard be applied when Emmanuel Macron does the same thing?

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, after TAFTA, after CETA, JEFTA joins the long list of free trade agreements that are losing to workers, losing out to our health and losing out to the planet. You make great speeches on the fight against climate change, but you do not mind voting for the most climate-fighting agreement of all time. You make great speeches about biodiversity, but you don't mind delivering the whales to the massacre. You are making great speeches about social Europe, but this agreement will level down workers' rights. And you always make great speeches about democracy, but you have accepted that national parliaments do not have a say.  That is why I voted against this agreement, which chooses multinationals over citizens.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the free trade agreement between the European Union and Japan was voted on at this plenary session of the European Parliament. But I dare say that 99% of Europe's citizens have no idea. And they have no idea why the European Commission wanted it that way. They want to negotiate with our rights and the planet without anyone knowing so no one can question it.  But this agreement is very similar to the TTIP being negotiated with the United States, or the one signed with Canada: all of them, agreements where multinationals have more power than states through arbitration courts, where public services that have been privatized are shielded, or where our environmental standards are of no use when Japan is one of the main timber markets from illegal logging or species fishing Protected.  The European Commission insists on a model that harms small producers, workers and SMEs, but which gives good benefits to large corporations. And it does so with the support of the European People's Party, the Liberals and the Social Democrats, also the PSOE. From the European left we voted against it.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the approval of JEFTA will have tremendous consequences for citizens. It is the most ambitious treaty negotiated by the European Union, but it cannot be discussed or amended in national parliaments. This issue is particularly scandalous because the process has been really opaque and the European Commission, in an outburzy of its supposed transparency, has only consulted the lobbies of large companies and corporate lobbies. This is how they succeed in imposing, as has already happened with CETA, the negative list approach to services, severely limiting the powers of governments to manage public services such as health, education and transport, or to promote their remuniciptalization.  JEFTA will grant unprecedented privileges to transnationals, including a mechanism that allows them to influence governments in a legislative manner. This is an intolerable reduction in democracy again, labour rights and the ability to combat financial speculation, for example. That's why we voted no to JEFTA.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I am, of course, in favour of an EU-Japan free trade agreement. I’m in favour of free trade, always and everywhere, and the deeper and more comprehensive, the better for all sides.  I just invite you to ponder the difference between these two archipelagos, these two island monarchies at either end of the Eurasian landmass and the different way in which they’re being treated as trade partners by the European Union. I don’t think anyone suggested, as part of the EU-Japan talks, that part of the Japanese archipelago – let’s say Honshu Island or something – should have to remain under EU regulations. Nor has anyone suggested that a trade deal would be tied to freedom of movement and nor, unless I wasn’t listening very carefully, did anyone say that Japan would have to remain in a customs union with the EU following the conclusion of such a trade deal. And it’s this sense – that the European Union is treating the UK, not in the sense of looking for a mutually advantageous outcome, but with a degree of vindictiveness as a special case –that I’m afraid makes a treaty now almost impossible to foresee.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The EU-Japan Free Trade Agreement is not perfect. The amendments tabled by my group have marked where we would have liked to have improved it. However, in my view, the fact that we did not get away with it is not a sufficient basis for rejection. I cannot mention the positive arrangements that I like about the agreement because of time constraints. Furthermore, there are not only economic and trade reasons to consider, but I believe that there are geostrategic reasons for defending multilateralism at a time when it is coming under pressure from two superpowers that are in favour of this agreement. That is why I have considered a 'yes' vote. In the end, I abstained out of loyalty to my group, which voted 'no' by a majority.

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in general and in solidarity with Japan and the people of Japan, I welcome this agreement. It is also a step towards a better and fairer EU trade policy that prioritises our regulatory standards on the environment and other key issues of importance to citizens. However, I do still have concerns, which is why in the end I abstained on the final vote on the resolution and on the agreement. Firstly, there are no proper arrangements in the agreement for monitoring of its impact on rail safety or in relation to the practical application and implementation of the opening—up of rail procurement processes in the EU and Japan. In addition, I would have preferred that this agreement were to definitively rule out, in advance, any investor protection through investor—state dispute settlement or an international investment court as being anti—democratic and inappropriate. Similarly, the agreement should have included more specific provisions providing protection for the right of nation—states to regulate, and guarding against the commercialisation of water and other public services.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I will thank the rapporteur, Peterle, for this report, because I think it is extremely important, and I am glad that in the end the text was approved in an ambitious form, as originally thought, because it is necessary not only to have economic relations with Japan, to have Japan not only as an economic partner, but as a key country in the Asia region. It is a great democracy, a strong economy, and in today's world, when we are fighting the challenges of the 21st century, terrorism, global problems, global and strong economies and democracies need to work together more closely, not just in economic terms. I am therefore very glad that this document has been approved, and I hope that it will lead to a further deepening of the links between the States of the European Union and Japan and, as I stress, not only in this economic area.

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, very often the areas of research and innovation are those on which the axe of myopic policies falls. On the other hand, we consider them to be of primary importance for the future of our citizens, for the flourishing of knowledge centres and for the soundness of our businesses, so that they are able to face the most important challenges. That is why we have indicated that as much as EUR 120 billion is needed for the Horizon Europe programme, which is precisely in support of research and innovation. I would like to stress that, in addition to the need for greater liaison with all stakeholders, we wanted to see the maintaining of an instrument for incremental research for small and medium-sized enterprises with a specific budget, obviously alongside other opportunities for disruptive research. From the point of view of pollution and resources, we have fought for a constraint on the use of the entire budget to combat climate change, to increase energy efficiency and to facilitate local self-handling and consumption initiatives. The text could have been further improved, but we must not forget that it is also the result of a close confrontation with those who have sometimes aimed more at satisfying the ings of large lobbies than at responding to the objective needs of society. However, we have achieved a compromise position that meets both the needs of stakeholders and the needs of people. Finally, although we will certainly have to ensure in future that the so-called principle of innovation does not backberle against our micro, small and medium-sized enterprises and citizens, we are voting in favour. It is in favour because we must not forget that change also involves supporting such important sectors, such as research and innovation.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, scientific research helped us to satisfy citizens’ priorities, both productivity and competitiveness. For centuries, ‘made in Europe’ has been a symbol of quality and knowhow. I even dare to say that the excellence in science, technology and the arts became a component of the EU’s normative power.  I support the proposal for a regulation on Horizon Europe and the report drafted by colleague, Dan Nica. This proposal serves the consolidation of the European Research Area and is going to deliver new jobs in science and research.  As a socialist and democrat, I defend the principle of open science and I believe that the diffusion of innovation makes the EU a unique scientific hub. However, we need to guarantee that our scientists choose to stay in Europe, because countries such as the United States, Canada and Australia appear attractive to researchers from Europe due to their larger innovation intensity and better social conditions. That is why we have to defend our social conditions in Europe.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, what more do we have to do to effectively prevent and investigate terrorism? Firstly, let us give investigative powers to Europol to prevent and investigate terrorism, cybercrime, organised crime and money laundering. Europol is now a specialised counter-terrorism agency, but it can only support Member States if they do, and some do not. He can do strategies, analyze data, but he can't do investigative paperwork. Terrorism and the financing of terrorism are cross-border and, as such, a single European agency, Europol, would make investigations more effective than investigations by Member States on the basis of cooperation in criminal matters. Also, obviously, the investigative powers must also come up with a financial supplement for Europol, but we need the effective fight against terrorism. Thanks.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, EU Member States are facing growing violence from far—right extremists and neo—fascist movements. They target political opponents, refugees and migrants, ethnic and religious minorities. Manifestations of these movements are seen everywhere in my country, Latvia, which is not an exclusion of this outrageous practice. The recent attack here in Strasbourg should be a reminder for us that the danger exists always. The role of the EU, which is expected by our citizens, is to detect and prevent such cases and to react rapidly whenever such things happen. For this, we need a strong and coordinated response and cooperation at the EU level. Security challenges become even more cross—border and that means that the reply should be cross—border too. Therefore, I welcome calling on the rapporteurs of all European institutions to work towards a common strategic culture, and the creation of the EU Coordination Centre for Victims of Terrorism is another necessary measure that the Commission should propose immediately.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the greatest danger to the security of the Union is the Kremlin's propaganda and, in particular, the actions of the Russian Federation, which seek to divide and dismantle the European Union and the non-Moscow states. The actions of the Russian Federation did not exist and do not exist without the complicity of some Member States and other States. In order to stop Russia from acting destructively in the Union's common foreign and security policy, it would be useful to waive the unanimity rule. The recent hostility in the Sea of Azov, as well as the use of fake news in reports of protests in France, Belgium or the Netherlands, call for a strong response from the Union. Illegal annexations, the migration crisis, cybercrime are all dangers that no Member State can face alone. Putin wants to divide us - divide et impera.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this report. I am very glad that the report has been well prepared, in my opinion it is more comprehensive, better than the previous year, because the human rights agenda is extremely important for the European Union. As a lawyer, I have been fighting all my life for the death penalty to be banned in the world, and I am very glad that the report describes that there is a certain decrease in executions, by about 7% to 8% year-on-year. But the decline is still small. I therefore wanted to call on the Institutions of the European Union not to underestimate this part of the fight for human rights, the fight against the inhumane death penalty, and to do our utmost in the following year to ensure that some countries stop using the death penalty or at least abuse it in political and other processes. I welcome the report, I supported it, and I hope that next year we will read that the human rights situation is improving in at least some areas and parts.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – Unfortunately, as has already become the rule in this parliamentary term, the 2017 Annual Report on Respect for Human Rights in the World gives a very distorted picture of what human rights are that need to be protected. A number of requirements contained in the adopted text go beyond the competences conferred on the Union in the European Treaties. Perhaps most surprisingly, the reference to the controversial Yoyayakart principles, a document proposed in the UN environment, was also included in the draft report, but was repeatedly rejected by both the UN General Assembly and the UN Human Rights Council and other intergovernmental institutions. I strongly oppose such attempts to promote false and misleading ideas about man and his nature in EU human rights policies, which is why I did not support the report.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I voted against this report. The European Union's human rights policy is instrumentally regarded as a tool for spreading the revolution – moral first and foremost – to the whole world, as a propaganda tube, as a trumpeting all the time about the rights of sexual minorities, which are blown up to the central problem of humanity in all our initiatives, trumpeting a specific approach to gender. Of course, this is about the Istanbul Convention, about the special role of women in everything in the world. So it's a tool to spread left-wing rhetoric around the world. We treat trade instrumentally when we say that we will only trade with those with whom we agree. This is an instrumental treatment of education when we say that education is to be a tool in the fight against radicalisation. No, education is a tool for communicating knowledge. If it is treated as a tool for creating attitudes, it is already propaganda. I therefore voted against and oppose this approach to human rights.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the Connecting Europe Facility promotes an energy model in the antipodes of what we need at this time of climate urgency. It promotes an unsustainable centralized model with mega-infrastructures such as the Midcat gas pipeline, the TAV or, for example, also the electrical interconnection of the Bay of Biscay.  Far from severing to finance fossil fuels, this Facility will continue to fund the so-called natural gas, which will continue to receive billions of euros when we know that its effects on climate are very, very harmful.  Nor does this fund put the principle of energy efficiency ahead of us, which is what we should do by making it easier to reduce our consumption rather than promoting infrastructures whose justification is more than doubtful.  In addition, the money to finance this Mechanism will come out of the reduction of the Cohesion Fund, the main instrument for correcting territorial inequalities within the European Union. Finally, it is advocating for the militarization of transport infrastructures, with the introduction of a pernicious dual civilian and military use: its way of making the military dimension enter... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Alex Mayer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I voted for this report and, as urged to by the UK Government, in support of the amendments to Articles 25 and 14, to provide more clarity on the opportunity for UK companies to continue to participate in EU space programmes post—Brexit.  The government are not right on very much at the moment, but on this they are correct about the potential impacts to UK space businesses. This is of vital importance to Airbus in Stevenage and Thales in Cambridge in my constituency. Indeed, the next phase of the Copernicus Programme could be worth GBP 700 million to UK industry.  This does rather underline how working out our future relationship before leaving the European Union really matters. Post—Brexit, the government won’t have any UK MEPs to amend legislation, to make it better for Britain, and the EU will be able to do whatever they like after we’ve left, and we will have no say. In fact, I worry that we face an astronomically bad deal.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the Connecting Europe Facility promotes an energy model in the antipodes of what we need at this time of global climate urgency. It promotes a centralized and unsustainable model with mega-infrastructures such as gas pipelines such as the Midcat, or the TAV, or the electrical interconnection of the Bay of Biscay. Far from shaving fossil fuels, the so-called natural gas will continue to receive billions of euros, when we know that its effects on the climate are very, very harmful.  Nor does this fund put the principle of energy efficiency ahead of us, which we should apply by prevailing by reducing our consumption rather than promoting mega-infrastructures whose justification is more than doubtful on many occasions. In addition, the money to finance the Mechanism will come out of the reduction of the European Cohesion Fund, the main instrument for correcting territorial inequalities within the European Union. Finally, it is advocating for militarizing transport infrastructures, introducing dual civilian and military use. And this is his way of getting the military dimension into the Union's sectoral policies and civil policies through the back door. We and we are defending a Europe of peace and ecological transition. That is why we voted no to this Mechanism.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I always vote against any way to raise taxes. If market taxation is unfairly distributed, then taxes should be reduced for those who pay them too high, not increased taxes for others. If Google or Facebook or other companies accumulate some wealth, they accumulate it as a result of voluntary transactions, and voluntary transactions are inherently good. Coercion is inherently bad, and taking away tax is a form of coercion, so I will always prefer that people get rich as a result of voluntary transactions rather than forced transactions (e.g. politicians who take money under duress from economic operators).  Secondly, this also requires the bureaucraticisation of the internet, just as, for example, the introduction of income tax required and still requires all economic traffic to be recorded today. If we want to introduce similar regulations on the internet, this will increase online reporting and increase internet surveillance by the state. And that's why I'm against it.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this motion for a resolution, and I am really very happy that this motion for a resolution passed with one amendment. It is our duty to protect the resources of European taxpayers, it is a matter for the European budget. I must stress here that the Czech Prime Minister is also trying to bring to the European level his argument that this is a campaign, that these are special-purpose products, attacks Czech non-profit organisations, such as Transparency International, in an indiscriminate way. However, it is the Czech Prime Minister who draws subsidies where he can, and yet his conflict of interest fundamentally damages the image of the Czech Republic in Europe. And I look away from fraud with European subsidies, which he obtained at the expense of small and medium-sized entrepreneurs and for which he is accused of crimes. I am also glad that the draft resolution draws attention to the dangerous concentration of political, economic and media power in the case of the Czech Prime Minister. For democratic rules to work, a system of brakes and countervailing must be guaranteed. The Czech Prime Minister bought or acquired a substantial part of these democratic brakes by concentrating power. That is why the Czech Republic is failing in its control and its reputation is undermined at the highest level.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the European Parliament made it clear in its vote today that Prime Minister Babiš has a real problem, a conflict of interest problem. What Andrej Babiš is making of this, the debate at the Czech level, the fact that this is a problem of the Czech political opposition and some journalists, has been refuted by this vote. This is a real problem, and the European Parliament resolution clearly states that the European Commission can and should properly, impartially and independently investigate whether Andrej Babiš is really in a conflict of interest and whether or not European money is being used legitimately or not. I think that this is very important, because this would make the Czech political problem, which would be difficult to solve at the level of the Czech authorities, whether executive or supervisory, because of the fact that Andrej Babiš is prime minister, will be addressed by the European institutions at the moment. It is European money, and the European institutions must therefore logically decide on this. Thanks to this debate, the Czech authorities have already become active. The Czech Ministry of Finance said today that it will not draw money for Agrofert.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, conflicts of interest, unregulated lobbying, decisions taken behind closed doors and lack of transparency are the main problems facing this Europe, which it still does not want to address, and which continue to widen the gap between the citizens and the European Union and the European institutions. This is the insight presented by this year's report by the Mediator, which has involved a whole series of senior positions in this Europe: Mr Juncker with the Selmayr case, but also Barroso, Katainen and President Draghi of the ECB. However, the European Mediator also offers us recommendations and solutions that we can put in place, and that is what we must do. Europe must listen to these recommendations, not least because the citizens of Europe deserve transparency, deserve a Europe based on the principles of ethics and moral integrity and deserve to know how decisions are taken, not least in order to avoid the phenomenon of always blaming Brussels, because our leaders sit at the tables of the European Council.  That is the wish of this report, which I am pleased to have been adopted by the majority of this House.

name: President. –
text: Good afternoon, colleagues. The sitting is resumed. I welcome the Commissioner. This is our last part—session before Christmas, so let’s make it an efficient and smooth one.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on rare diseases by Mairead McGuinness, Rory Palmer, Jadwiga Wiśniewska, Gesine Meissner, Tilly Metz, Estefanía Torres Martínez and Piernicola Pedicini, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000118/2018 — B8—0419/2018).

name: Gesine Meissner
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has We are only a few. That's clear: it's just before Christmas, and most are already gone. Before Christmas, we also want to deal with beautiful things and not with illnesses, that is clear. We all want stable health. One might also think that, as we are positioned in Europe with medical research, almost everything is actually good. The point is that there are diseases that are so rare that not everything is good. And we want to improve that. Rare diseases are usually referred to when fewer than 2 000 people are affected. In terms of the European Union, this is still a relatively large number of people who may have rare diseases. Overall, it is said, there are 6 000 to 8 000 rare diseases in the European Union, but in total 30 million out of 500 million people are affected – a significant number. And you have to think: what does this mean for these people? This means for these people that when they get the diagnosis – which I hope is a correct one, because you can also be unsafe with the diagnosis in rare diseases – there are big question marks, great uncertainty, not only among the doctors, but also, of course, with the family. Normally you think that when a person gets sick, you have a drug. You can take that, and then everything will be fine. As I said earlier, this is precisely not the case in this case. I am now very personal. I can say this out of my own concern. My father died early from a rare disease, my brother died very early as a child from a rare disease. In both cases, the research came too late and there were no ways to help them. With my father, who was a well-known politician – and I say this very personally – it was the case that we ourselves, as a family, also said: we do not want to allow research, we do not want to put it on display. It might have been wrong, it might have been selfish, but we had made such a decision. My own son fell ill six years ago with an unrecognized disease. It was the first case in the world, and it is still being investigated today. And here, too, I know that, of course, research helps him, because he says that he knows that research on his illness, which was so unique, has already helped many people. That is, of course, a good thing. But it is the case that it could not help him himself. Not only is there no suitable diagnosis, there is no known treatment. It is trial and error that must be made from the heart. I have just experienced it myself several times, especially with my son, how trial and error can lead to success and save life, but of course cannot help permanently. And these are things we want to improve. That is why it is very important that we make research possible and that we also see: how can we ensure funding, how can we improve the networks that already exist in order to improve the needs of the people it concerns in the future. It is just the case: on the one hand, medicine is already very advanced, and on the other hand, in some respects, it is still in its infancy, because there can always be new cases, especially due to tropical diseases. My son was diagnosed with a tropical virus that has not been detected to date, although many are trying to figure out what it was. In this context, it is very important for us to see what can be done to give people access to treatment, good diagnosis and also appropriate medicines throughout the EU.  To this end, we have worked out various questions which I shall now read out.  The first question to the Commission is this: what measures has the Commission taken so far to ensure accurate and early diagnosis of rare diseases and access to affordable medicines needed to treat them across the EU? How does the Commission promote research on rare diseases and the development of new or better early detection methods, and how does it intend to promote these efforts and achieve measurably better results in rare disease patients in all EU Member States? Secondly, how does the Commission intend to ensure access to information, medicines and medical treatments for rare disease patients across the EU? In view of the fact that access to early and accurate diagnoses can have a significant impact on patients' prognosis and quality of life, how does the Commission encourage the improvement of coordination and learning processes in all areas of Member states? Thirdly, what plans does the Commission have to ensure the permanent funding of patient organisations that support the European reference networks for rare diseases, for example through the common European programme for rare diseases?

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all, as the Commission and other Commissioners and Members of this House have done along these past two days, please allow me to express my solidarity with the families of the victims of the terrible attack here in Strasbourg. Now we have three deaths and that is very painful for me as a medical doctor.  Secondly, I would like to tell Ms Meissner that she has just opened my heart and I give her my words of sympathy because of such an experience. In the 20 years of work on rare diseases the Commission has fostered network structures for action and expertise. It has developed a policy framework with Member States and encouraged innovative ways of working. Mr President, I have six questions, which – if I may say – will be impossible to answer in three minutes because I know those questions are very detailed.
